column2: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7--It was in the sixth inning today that Henry Aaron left the on-deck circle and advanced toward the plate, swinging two bats. One was the loaded war club that's used only for practice swings. The other was his regular bat.

The Soviet space satellite continues to be at the center of world attention. From all nations comes deserved applause for the high order of scientific and technical craftsmanship which made this feat possible.
School attendance slumped sharply throughout the city yesterday as a result of the Asian influenza epidemic.
WASHINGTON, Oct, 7--New York today was promised a prompt official answer to its protest that the city had been short-changed in the counting of its population last spring.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)-- The Government charged today that the Procter Gamble Company violated the antimerger law in acquiring they Clorox Chemical Company of Oakland, Calif.
The Milwaukee Braves and New York Yankees arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--Despite substantial reductions in the armed forces, Government officials do not foresee any end to the draft soon.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 7 --Shelley Mayfield of the Meadow Brook Club dropped a 3-foot putt on the final hole to finish 70, 73-143 and deadlock with Don Brown of Piping Rock, 73, 70-143, for the Long Island P.G.A, championship
On Sunday night the Royal Ballet took leave of the Metropolitan Opera House. Yesterday, the opera personnel moved in and took over.
The city and county of San Francisco, received bids yesterday on bond issues totaling $28,900,000.
Howard McSpedon, prominent labor leader in the city's construction industry, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 6016 Delafield Avenue, the Bronx, in his fifty-sixth year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--The Justice Department threatened today to go to court, if necessary, to block a move by the American Telephone and Teleoraph Company in the field of private mobile radio communications.
BONN, Oct. 7--The launching of the Soviet satellite and its progress around the world dominated all other news in Germany today.

The United States would be fully justified in severing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and sending the Russian Ambassador home, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald, said yesterday.

Pedro Oscar Mayorga and Mrs.Mayorga, members of the Argentine team of horse show riders, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for the events in New York, Harrisburg and Toronto.

The twelfth annual Regional Plan Conference heard yesterday that needs of the metropolitan region in the next twenty years would require civic and business support to "match emerging governmental leadership."
The dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism said last night that most of the nation's magazines and newspaper's underestimated the intelligence of their readers.
One of the biggest disappointments in Myrna Jablow's life occurred when she learned that girls couldn't be water-boys for New Utrecht's football team.
When a business ceases to think about going forward, and would be content to hold even, then the next logical hope is to slow the rate of decline to avoid going out of business altogether.
DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 7 --Immediately after dinner tonight, Bobby Marr, Deerfield Academy's head football coach, made a beeline for the school's spacious infirmary.

The five-and-one-half-story apartment building at 1894-6 Walton Avenue, at the southeast corner of 177th Street, in the Bronx has been purchased and immediately resold by Geisinger Germain, operators.

The Rhodesian Selection Trust group of copper mining companies, major suppliers to the British market, returned yesterday to its policy of basing copper prices on the daily quotations of the London Metal Exchange.
The National Hockey League will open its forty-first season tonight when the Toronto Maple Leafs meet the Black Hawks at Chicago.
HERE we are in the marvellous world of screen, radio, recordings and television, all of which transcend the human race.
GENEVA, Oct. 7--A Jewish welfare agency banned in Poland since 1949 has been asked by the Polish Government to resume its rehabilitation work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--Defense Department officials began an intensive study today of the implications of the launching of a Soviet satellite for the United States military and scientific rocket programs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--An attorney for the Teamsters Union told Senate investigators last night that subpoenaed documents relating to the election of James R. Hoffa as president had been thrown into an incinerator in Miami Beach.
The Soviet Union's successful earth satellite put Wall Street investors on the defensive yesterday.
GEORGE LONDON'S singing of Mussorgsky's "Songs and Dances of Death" was the highlight at Town Hall last night as the Little Orchestra Society opened its eleventh season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--Senatorial reaction to the Soviet earth satellite divided along partisan lines today.
For the first time since early February, the pound yesterday reached its parity rate of $2.80 with the United States dollar both here and in London. In New York it closed at $2.80 1/16.
AS if America's roads weren't crowded enough, Stern's now wants to create a traffic jam on the sidewalks.
The Board of Education proposed yesterday a city school construction fund of $800,000,000 spread over the next eight capital budgets.
Soviet scientists were reported yester day to have offered to put United States scientific instruments in one of their satellites.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7--Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union was willing to bring the earth satellite and all pilotless missiles under international control as part of a general agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 7 (AP)--A foreign news analyst for The Associated Press said today "we can expect the Russians to bring out other surprisds," such as the first earth satellite.
The Iranian Govermnent's Plan Organiaztion has authorized a private United States company to undertake a vast development program in the Khuzestan region of southwestern Iran.
At a moment when the world is weighing the military implications of the Soviet rocket machinery that hurled a man-made moon-into space, ...
William R. Rose, former banker of Ellenville, N.Y., yesterday pleaded guilty in Federal Court to seventeen counts of misappropriating bank funds.
The musicians of the New York Philharmonic voted yesterday to break off contract negotiations with the PhilharmonicSymphony Society of New York.
Charles L.Patterson voluntarily acknowledged yesterday that some kind of wage increase was in prospect for the Transit Authority's 32,268 hourly rated employes.
Steel production increased slightly last week, for the fourth consecutive week. But operations were scheduled to slow a bit this week.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 (AP)--A Federal judge today approved a plan for the sale of the bankrupt Northeastern Steel Company of Bridgeport to the Carpenter Steel Company of Reading, Pa.
PARIS, Oct. 7--A top French aviation expert warned today that Soviet scientific accomplishments were making it possible for the Russians to "win the peace without ever having to make war."
WASHINGTON, Oct.7 (UP)-- The real estate value of the nation's farms rose 8 per cent in the year ended July 1 to a record high of $112,400,000,000, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
T.T. Krishnamachari, Finance Minister of India, made an earnest plea yesterday for an understanding of his country's position as between East and West.
Dr. Jekuthiel Ginsburg, professor of mathematics and director of the Institute of Mathematics at Yeshiva University, ied yesterday of a heart atack at his home, 610 West 39th Street. His age was 68.
"Mary Stuart," starring Eva Le Gallienne (Queen Elizabeth) and Irene Worth (title role), will usher in the fifth season of the Phoenix Theatre at 7:45 o'clock tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7--The City Council opened the way late today for the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team to move here as soon as it wants.

Two new diseases, among the most dreadful-sounding of the afflictions known to medical science--as well as among the most difficult to spell--are the subjects of an exhibit at the New York Academy of Medicine this week.
The American Gas Association yesterday elected Robert W, Otto president at its annual meeting in St.Louis.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7--There was today, for the first time in this world series, an air of sadness in the Yankee dressing room.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--The Supreme Court reconvened today and removed from its hearing calendar two of the most controversial cases on its docket.

The nation's youth must be taught to appreciate the importance of science or the United States' way of life is "doomed to rapid extinction," the director of the American Institute of Physics said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct.7(AP)-- Charges of misrepresenting merchandise were filed by the Federal Trade Commission today against three New York companies selling watches.
ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP)--A state advisory committee said today there were substantial inequities in local tax rolls and called for overhaul of assessment procedures.
Prices for theatre tickets are higher today than they were thirty years ago, but no higher, percentage-wise, than they are for such commodities as "automobiles, subway fares and round steaks."
BUDAAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 3 --The youths who sparked Hungary's revolt last October have largely turned their backs on politics and sullenly resumed their studies.
Federal air agencies are planning to put into operation on Nov. 1 the first phase of a new High-altitude air traffic control plan.
Following are the texts of Gov. Orval E. Faubus' letter to the Army commander in Little Rock and a statement by Wilber M. Brucker, Army Secretary:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7--French military commanders in North Africa were charged here today with seeking a pretest to invade Tunisia.
SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 7 (AP)--Texas Eastern Transmission. Corporation today filed a $32,235,000 civil damage suit against nine operating barge companies, three oil companies and one individual.
A Li'l Abner tea dance will be given in the ballroom of the Ambassador on the afternoon of Dec. 3 for the benefit of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 --Dr. Fred L. Whipple, director of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, said tonight that it might be possible to see the Russian satellite in this vicinity tomorrow about 8 A.M.
The Vermont Electric Power Company has placed privately with ten institutional investors $10,500,000 of 4.95 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1985 the company announced.
WASHINGTON, October 7-- Mrs. Gertrude Clarke Whittall was the honored guest at a concert at the Library of Congress tonight.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7--There were several heroes in the Braves' dressing room today after their thrilling victory over the Yankees.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 7 --Fort the first time in forty years Democrats today won control of the Government in Monroe.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 7 --A baby elephant, a gift from school children in Mercara, Coorg, India, to their fellow students in Darien, was delivered here this afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 --The writers of Hollywood seem certain to get their own television spectacular this February if current negotiations between the National Broadcasting Company and the Writers...

ELKINS, N.H., Oct. 8-- Link Parks, who operates Pleasant Lake Lodge here, says that any sportsman who can't kill grouse, woodcock and trout around here in one day ought to take up the collection of old porcelain, and forget about Daniel Boone. He has a fair case, as today's events seemed to prove.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 8. (AP)-- Harold S. Falk, president of the Falk Corporation, died at his home late yesterday. His age was 73.

SEVEN women who have ruled Britain in one period or another in the last 800 years are posed this morning in the north window of the British Overseas Airways Corporatipn at 530 Fifth Avenue. Window dressers worked through the night to set them there.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 8 --Army finds itself in the unaccustomed role of favorite over Notre Dame for the renewal of their intersectional football rivalry at Philadelphia Saturday after a ten-year interlude. But don't try to peddle that to Earl (Red) Blaik.
The Dodgers will play their baseball in Los Angeles next year. The Brooklyn Baseball Club announced yesterday it was proceeding with the necessary steps to move to Los Angeles.
DENVER, Oct. 7--The American Civil Liberties Union protested last night the dismissal of a rocket research scientist for "talking too much."

An innovation in American sports car competition will be introduced at the Lime Rock, Conn., mile and a half track on Saturday, when a field of forty saloon-type importations will engage in a ten-hour endurance test.

ALBANY, Oct. 8--The complex legal and ecclesiastical dispute that has divided the parish of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn for a decade was carried to the state's highest court today.

In deserting Brooklyn for Los Angeles, the Dodgers will leave an aching void in the Borough of Churches. Few baseball clubs have had greater identity with, and greater impact on, their communities than the Dodgers have had on Brooklyn.

NEWARK, Oct. 8--Malcolm S. Forbes, campaigning in Essex County, again gave priority today to a report accusing Democratic state officials of "gross neglect" in their handling of the Loyalty Insurance Group investigation.

The voice of the Soviet earth satellite faltered yesterday and for six hours was silent. Beginning about Monday night, observers in many parts of the world reported that ... the signal had shifted from a rhythmic beeping to a steady signal or had vanished altogether.

From the Soviet point of view, the Iron Curtain now is around the United States, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8-- President Eisenhower held an hour-long conference with top scientists and defense officials today on United States missile and satellite programs and those of the Soviet Union.
The Devoe Raynolds Company yesterday reported an increase in sales but a decline in profits for the nine months ended with August.

IN the early Nineteen Hundreds, when it was smart to live on the right side of the tracks (Fifth Avenue) rather than directly above them (Park Avenue), a career-minded teenager discovered the effectiveness of a good address.

IT'S a shame that the world series had to move out of Milwaukee. It was just beginning to attract new customers. After two days of identical figures of 45,804, the crowd swelled enormously for the third day as it rocketed up to 45,811. It was a happy augury for the future except that there ain't no future.

Joseph A. Solovei, Brooklyn lawyer and controversial figure in the Drukman murder case in 1935, was named last night by Mayor Wagner to be a Municipal Court Justice.

While the military and political significance of the new Soviet rockets that launched a man-made moon is being studied in all world capitals the problems arising from this new development have come up for immediate discussion at two points.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York has been authorized by the Public Service Commission to invite public bidding on $60,000,000 of mortgage bonds, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Canada received from the United States today assurances against renewal of a recently abandoned system of bartering surplus wheat abroad, a system that had brought Canadian complaints.
Jack Soble, former head of a Soviet espionage ring in this country, was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison.

Two opposing candidates for Borough President of Queens found themselves in agreement on one point yesterday. They both contended that Queens was being short-changed in projected new school construction in 1958.
Wholesale food markets it New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Baltimore were described yesterday as "obsolete, antiquated ratholes."

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (UP)--Ted Lindsay and Glenn Hall, a pair of summertime acquisitions from the Detroit Red Wings, tonight led the Chicago Black Hawks to a victory in the first game of the National Hockey League season mith a 1-0 shutout of the Toronto Maple Leafs.
The Falstaff Brewing Corporation has completed plans to acquire the Griesedieck Brothers Brewing Company, both of St. ...

Meetings are being held to plan the Nov. 15 benefit "A Night at The Lambs," which will aid the Girls Club of New York. The event will include a prefatory dinner at The Lambs clubhouse, 128 West Fortyfourth Street, and the preview of a new play in the club auditorium.
AN exhibition of sculpture in silver and gold by the Italian artist Renato Signorini opened yesterday at Tiffany Co., 727 Fifth Avenue.

WITH "Mary Stuart," which opened last evening, the Phoenix Theatre has at last got off-center. Script, direction and acting restore to the Phoenix the high excitement and high purpose that almost vanished last season.

Absenteeism in the city schools rose again yesterday. At the same time municipal hospitals reported treating nearly twice, as many cases of influenza and upper respiratory infections on Monday as they had on Sunday.

A look at West Germany and its Chancellor is presented in Edgar Alexander's new book called "Adenauer and the New Germany: The Chancellor of the Vanquished." Farrar, Straus Cudahy will publish it Nov. 8.

An issue of $25,000,000 of preferred stock in the Commonwealth Edison Company is being offered for public subscription today by a banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Glore, Forgan Co.
Five loft buildings at 428 to 434 East Tenth Street running through the block to 735-39 East Ninth Street, between Avenues C and D, have been sold by Leonard J. Winston, realty...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP)-- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's cotton crop at 12,401,000 bales, 312,000 bales below last month's estimate.

The value of the nation's farm real estate rose 8 per cent during the year ended June 30, and has apparently been climbing at roughly the same rate since that time, according to a report just released by the Department of Agriculture.
WARSAW, Oct. 8--The cosmic beep of the Soviet celestial satellite thus far has had little more political repercussion among the Soviet political satellites than a damp squib.
Ohio borrowed $31,000,000 yesterday to finance the construction of highways. The money was raised by the sale of bonds secured by motor vehicle taxes at an interest cost of 3.324 per cent.

"The Egghead," starring Karl Malden, arrives at 8 o'clock tonight at the Barrymore. The new drama will introduce Molly Kazan, wife of the stage and screen director, Elia Kazan, to the ranks of Broadway playwrights.

The income tax returns of prospective jurors in a trial of Frank Costello were screened by an Internal Revenue agent, it was testified yesterday in Federal Court. The gambler was on trial in 1954 for income tax evasion, and was convicted.
The timetable of the high command of the merged labor federation was reshuffled yesterday to put maximum pressure on the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Red Sullivan was skating on thin ice eleven months ago. For five days the fiery New York Ranger center was on the critical list at St. Clare's Hospital after being "speared" with a hockey stick in a game against the Boston Bruins.

TOKYO, Oct. 8--An adverse balance in visible trade of $910,931,000 for the first six months of Japan's 1957 fiscal year-- April through September--was reported yesterday by the Ministry of Finance.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan reported yesterday that his office was investigating the Traffic Courts in New York County.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8-- Gov. Robert B. Meyner invaded the Republican stronghold of Atlantic County today in his bid for a second four-year term.

"Studio One" has been renewed through 1959 by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, sponsor of the television drama series since May 11, 1949. The two-year renewal contract becomes effective Jan. 1.
After the brutal Soviet suppression of the Hungarian revolt last fall some 35,000 refugees from the slaughter, who had escaped mostly into Austria, were given asylum in the United States.

A little more than a year from now--in 1959--The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, Cooper Square, New York 3, will have completed a century of devoted service to New York City and the nation.

Hope, despair, regret, bewilderment and surprise were some of the emotions Casey Stengel felt yesterday. Time hung heavy on the hands of the Yankee skipper, who had assembled his athletes for a workout but had no place for them to work. Rain had made the Stadium grounds, especially the outfield, unplayable.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Oct. 8--The Army's newest high-power direction finder is being used to track the satellite's orbit as far as half-way around the globe, the Army announced today.

The International Boxing Club adopted a policy yesterday aimed at developing more mainevent boxers to overcome an existing shortage.
THE second program of Shanta Rao and her Dancers of India, which opened last night for the remainder of the engagement at the ANTA Theatre, is a vast improvement over the first one.
Mayor Wagner cited last night the expenditure of $300,000,000 for public improvements in Queens as evidence of his Administration's concern with the needs of that growing borough.
GIMBELS, after a six-week treasure hunt all over Eur ope, has returned with some of the most delectable and useful clothes any child ever drooled on, or grandmother ever drooled over.
Benjamin McKelway succeed ed Robert McLean yesterday as president of The Associated Press.
LULEA, Sweden, Oct. 8-- There is nothing wrong with making a profit while fighting communism, judging from the "Meet America" campaign begun here today in this city's biggest business enterprise.

DIARIES in book form are likely to have more ennuis than rewards for the average reader. Stevenson (the man who wrote "Treasure Island," not the man who ran for President) called them exercises in "melancholy self-deception."

PARIS, Oct. 7--Writing in the afternoon newspaper ParisPresse today, Jean Fabiani commented that the launching of the Soviet satellite was a rude awakening for the free world, long "soothed by its belief in the indisputable and invulnerable superiority of America." Similar comments were made by other Europeans.

EAR plugs are in order for the woman of the house who at tends the second annual New York High Fidelity Show in the New York Trade Show building, Eighth Avenue at Thirty-fifth Street this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8-- Plans for new military research projects have been brought to a virtual standstill by limitations on spending.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 8 (AP) --Garden State Park tomorrow opens its twenty-five-day fall meeting, which will include the Garden State Stakes, the world's richest race and its companion event, the $50,000 added Gardenia stakes.

More than 100 residents of the Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged and Indigent Females in the City of New York have been preparing many articles to be sold at the annual bazaar for the benefit of the organization. LONDON, Oct. 8--The continuing strength of sterling today had a buoyant effect on British Government securities and a steadying influence on stocks.

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Oct. 8--Through the years Bill Rineer, Mount Hermon's head football coach, has scrupulously tried to keep his squad healthy. He has been surprisingly successful.

Walt Whitman, the good gray poet, lived in West Babylon and fished in Gilmore's Pond. He thought the pond was in West Babylon.

A leader of the Ghana Government who had entertained Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Adlai E. Stevenson in his home said yesterday he had been denied service in a restaurant in Dover, Del., because of his color.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP)--Willie Toweel of South Africa, the British Empire lightweight champion, tonight outpointed Jimmy Carter of New York, a former world champion, in a non-title ten-round bout at London's Royal Albert Hall. Each man weighed 137 pounds.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 8 --Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today he had received "about a dozen" complaints that Federal paratroopers had invaded girls' dressing rooms at Central High School.
The 1957 world series returns to New York today for Act 6. Already there have been more surprises than anyone deemed possible. What happens next is anybody's guess.

Mayor Wagner toured Manhattan polling places last night in an effort to spur interest in registration.

The burden of 168 pounds failed to hinder Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji in the $32,250 Grand National Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Taking the lead only at the final jump in the race of about three miles and a furlong, the 4-5 favorite nevertheless, scored a decisive triumph.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an appeal by a seamen's union against an injunction in the fifty-two-day strike against the Bull Line.

Carl Rosenberger, founder and chairman of the board of Coro, Inc., a leading manufacturer of costume jewelry, died Monday night of a heart attack in his apartment at the Waldorf Towers. He was 85 years old.

LONDON, Oct. 8--The British Government is expected to concur in the United States' suggestion that a study of the control of objects entering outer space be initiated without awaiting action on other aspects of disarmament.
Fred Haney caught up on his sleep until after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. After his nap, the Braves' manager voiced a lot of confidence in his Braves.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 --Susan Hayward will star in "The Barbara Graham Story," tentative title for a motion picture based on a sensational California murder trial.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 7-- The increase in the number of Americans in South Vietnam has had little effect on relations with the Vietnamese people. Despite occasional rumors of growing anti-American trends there has been no substantial evidence to support such charges.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it expected "considerable trouble" in reaching a new labor agreement because of money.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8 --Wearing two hats around Harvard is just part of the job for Fred Lawrence Whipple. But when the Russians launched their satellite without warning, he found himself wearing a third.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 8-- A new Abraham Straus department store will be opened to the public at 10 A.M. tomorrow. At a special preview today, 5,000 invited residents of Suffolk County inspected the two-story building.
Few baseball fans will be more unhappy over next season's shift of the Dodgers and Giants to the West Coast than Charles L. Patterson, Joseph E. O'Grady and E. Vincent Curtayne.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8-- Westchester County's method for the listing of voters under the new permanent personal registration system was declared illegal today by Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher. The method has been in use since May.
Medicine to postpone menstruation in women as long as might be desired was described here yesterday at a conference sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences.
BALBOA, C.Z., Oct. 7--Acting Gov. Hugh M. Arnold told the Panama Canal Engineering Society last night that a hearing to review toll rates in the canal was inevitable.
HUNDREDS of Danish peeled shrimp no bigger than a dime have been packed handsomely in a ten-ounce glass jar that is one of the new foods of note at Maison Glass, 52 East Fifty-eighth Street.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 8 --The United States could have had an earth satellite in the sky as long as two years ago if the Army had not received orders to halt its program, two United States generals declared today.
Small but plentiful losses peppered the New York Stock Exchange list yesterday and the market as a whole made a new low for the year.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 (AP)-- The Western and Southern Life Insurance Company of Cincinnati announced today that it had acquired the controlling interest in the Texas Prudential...
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8-- Princeton Theological Seminary dedicated its new $1,700,000 Robert E. Speer Library today.

Atlas Corporation stockholders elected yesterday eight directors, including two new ones, approved auditors and defeated a proposal for cumulative voting. A record turnout of more than 600 persons attended the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The first telephone cable connecting the United States and the Hawaiian Islands was opened to public service here today. Conversations formerly were transmitted by radio telephone.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8-- The favored Sir Nevis, owned and driven by Joe Dodge of Orangeburg, N.Y., won the $4,050 Manhasset Trot by three-quarters of a length at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Timed in 2:07 1/5, Sir Nevis returned $8.10 for $2.
The Stauffer Chemical Company has found that the most efficient way to ship zirconium tetrachloride--the principal raw material for making the nuclear reactor structural metal zirconium--...
Two companies that recently moved to new agencies have announced plans for revamped campaigns.

The American Motors Corporation's 1958 Rambler line will cost 4 per cent more than the 1957 models. The prices, which will range from $125 to $225 higher, give the first indication of the 1958 automotive price pattern.
Each time a crime is committed there is a threat to civil liberties and human life, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8-- United States officials said today that the State Department would "certainly" put it up to Congress if India made an expected request for a loan of about $500,000,000.

NIKKO, Japan, Oct .8--Official Japan's attitude toward the agonies of racial conflict in the United States is best symbolized by the famous original three monkeys carved upon a frieze adorning the venerable Toshogu Shrine here. This trio, while gazing benignly from a holy mountain, refuses either to hear, speak or see evil.

For those New Yorkers who like to drive out of the city to see autumn colors, the Long Island State Park Commission suggests a visit to the Cutting Arboretum at Great River, L.I., where the foliage is already a delight to see. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8--The Tunisian delegation announced today that it would present the Algerian nationalist Viewpoint during the United Nations debate on Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The Census Bureau made official today that the special New York population count last spring registered 7,795,471 residents. That was 96,486 fewer than in 1950, or a drop of 1.2 per cent.

Army crashed the top ten in the only major change in the weekly college football ratings by the United Press board of coaches. Oklahoma and Michigan State remained solidly entrenched in the 1-2 spots.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 9--State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes accused Gov. Robert B. Meyner today of having failed to meet constitutional responsibilities in the field of education.

PARIS, Oct. 9--The latest Soviet technical advances call for a critical review of the strategy of the North Atlantic Alliance and for a new kind of leadership by the United States, in the view of European officials intimately associated with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 9 (UP)--An American lawyer said today that the United Nations must declare the moon an independent area to keep any nation from claiming it as a possession.
Robert Cummings has been signed for a major role in the musical version of "Junior Miss," which will be televised in colon by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Dec. 20 from 7:30 to 9 P. M.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 9 (AP)-- Mike DeJohn scored a firstround knockout of the heavily favored Alex Miteff of Argentina tonight in a scheduled tenround fight. A rocking left hook halted the action at 1:17 of the first round.
New York University balanced its budget for the fiscal year ended June 30 with income and expenses reaching record highs of more than $42,000,000 each.

Snails are receiving the official attention of the United States Golf Association. These are not the garden variety nor are they related to escargots, which are served in discriminating French restaurants.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I. Oct. 9-- Mitchel College of Long Island University will be dedicated at Mitchel Air Force Base here next Monday afternoon.
LEVITTOWN, L.I. Oct. 9-- This 17,447-home community, celebrating its tenth anniversary, starts its three-day festival tomorrow with the theme of "cultural progress day."
The National Maritime Union voted yesterday to help the International Longshoremen's Association back into the house of labor.

WHEN the subject is fish, the question is frequently "to bone or not to bone before cooking?" Though such a choice might seem less than significant to those with small affinity for fin fare, it can become a matter of great concern to cooks confronted with fresh-caught hauls.

In a bit over ten years Maurice Olen has built a chain of general retail stores from a standing start--one store in Pensacola, Fla., and another in Mobile, Ala. There are now 107, with more under construction.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 9--A tentative plan to correct a deficiency in Westchester County's permanent personal registration system was agreed upon by torneys here today. It would cause a minimum of inconvenience to voters who have registered since May 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct 9--The United States will urge the United Nations tomorrow to .approve a disarmament program providing assurances that objects moving through outer space are used solely for peaceful purposes.
Earnings of the Illinois Central Railroad last month were 50 per cent below the 1956 level.
IN "The Egghead," which was produced at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last evening, Molly Kazan has written a thesis play about a college professor deceived by a Communist.
Safeway Stores, Inc., has signed a lease for a supermarket building at the southwest corner of Westchester Avenue and Cauldwell Avenue, the Bronx.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 9 (AP)--Six Notre Dame starters and two second-stringers were confined to bed with influenza tonight and Coach Terry Brennan said his team was "hurt badly" for Saturday's game with Army at Philadelphia.
WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 9-- "We'll be much less in need if we can turn on some speed."
Bold Ruler came through with the performance of a true champion in the Vosburgh Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old son of Nasrullah gave away weight to seven rivals,
Cotton futures rose 12 to 23 points (60 cents to $1.15 a bale) on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Activity was moderate.
A total of 144,658 persons qualified to vote in the Nov. 5 city election yesterday in the biggest turnout since the first day of registration Sept. 28.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--The Federal Trade Commission issued a double-barreled complaint today against gasoline sales activities of the Texas Company.
CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 9 (AP)-- The racing compass in New Jersey moved back to its starting point today as Garden State Park opened its gates for the final twenty-five-day period of the year.

"Romanoff and Juliet," written by and starring Peter Ustinov, will have its Broadway premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Plymouth Theatre.

ELKINS, N.H., Oct. 9-- Let's see, now, how this goes. It was not raining at 7 A.M. today, but it had been raining and it looked like more rain. It was certain that the woods would be wet.
The reduction of New York City's sales tax from 3 to 2 per cent was proposed yesterday by the Republican candidate for City Controller.

TODAY, 4:30 P.M.: "Kioni's Poi Pounder," a film, will be shown free at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. At the same hour on Friday, Tuesday and Wednesday, other children's films will also be shown.

The state of Washington announced yesterday a proposed offering of $52,000,000 of public school plant and facility bonds on Oct. 29. To be dated Nov. 1, 1957, the bonds are limited to a 4 per cent coupon and will mature on Nov. 1 from 1958 to 1972.
Joseph Tomlinson, insurgent director of Loew's, Inc., and its largest single stockholder, yesterday asked shareholders to revoke proxies given to the management.

Sales of resilient flooring are holding steady despite the decline in home building. Volume has been helped by the trend toward home improvement and is offsetting the slack caused by the drop in new housing.

The long ball and the fast ball for years have been the hallmarks of Yankee success. So it was particularly appropriate that yesterday's Bomber heroes of the series-tying victory over the Braves were fellows who have helped perpetuate this tradition.

Trading stamps, which housewives diligently save to get premiums ranging from a coffee pot to a mink coat, were described yesterday as both a boon and a bane to retail merchants.
THE world series returned yesterday to its starting point of a week ago and it became immediately obvious that not an awful lot had been accomplished in the interim.

The San Francisco Bay area, the largest and most important harbor on the Pacific Coast, is the subject of two books to be published this month. Both volumes have the title "San Francisco Bay." One will be issued Oct. 24 by Doubleday.

A compromise that might enable a Long Island bank to open for business despite a disputed boundary line was suggested yesterday.

THE first event in the third season of New Music Con certs, last night in Carl Fischer Hall, provided an unusual idea that resulted in an unusual program. Eric Simon, the organizer and conductor of the concerts, elected to present three posthumously published works by as many modern composers.

MAEBASHI, Japan, Thursday, Oct. 10 (UP)--The widower of Mme. Naka Sakai testified in the manslaughter trial of Specialist 3/C William S. Girard today that he had warned his wife "numerous times" to stay out of the Camp Weir firing range.

A program for adding 446 men to the Police Department and 195 to the Fire Department by next June 1 was mapped yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The ultimate cost of the new jobs will be $3,000,000 a year.

A report recommending that the City Housing Authority Police force be reorganized and its numbers increased by 250 men was recommended yesterday by former Police Commissioned Arthur W. Wallander. The increase would more than double the present force of 236 men.

THE New York City Opera Company began its new season at the City Center last night with a remarkably fine "Turandot." Puccini's last opera is a challenge to the greatest opera houses, and one shuddered in advance at this company's temerity.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 9-- Dr. George Malcolm Stratton, founder of the University of California's Department of Psychology, died at his home here today. He was 92 years old.

THE legend of Dylan Thomas, 1914-54, is now greater than any of his poems, his stories or his plays. It is regularly said that he destroyed himself; it is not so frequently noted how much he did to invent himself--or what strange help he had in achieving the ample dimensions of that creation.

The nation's steel production in September was at the nextto-the-lowest level so far this year, and 13.7 per cent below output a year earlier.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 11-- Britain's First Lord of the Admiralty, the Earl of Selkirk, expressed confidence today that his country would support the United States in assurances of defending Turkey in the event of aggression.
A READER submits a recipe for Sauce Verde that she states can be made for 50 cents. This is a green sauce recently mentioned in these columns.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 11--The Communists proposed to the United Nations Command today that trade be opened between North and South Korea through designated points of entry across the demilitarized zone.
The affidavits of support filled out by sponsors of nearly all immigrants to this country since 1924 have been ruled unenforceable.
MANILA, Oct. 11. (AP)-- Carlos P. Romulo Jr. and five American business men were killed in a plane crash south of Manila today.

A compromise appeal for permission to accept $165,000 in connection with the crash of a Northeast Airlines plane on Rilcers Island last Feb. 1 was filed yesterday in Bronx Surrogate's Court.

Less than twenty-four hours after an announcement that "A Soft Touch" would open at the Music Box on Nov. 13, a spokesman for the attraction confirmed a report yesterday that it had been "indefinitely suspended."

ROME, Oct. 11--Prof. Federico Bigi, head of the provisional Government of San Marino, which today deposed the tiny republic's Communist regime, does not look the part of an insurgent who could turn such a trick.

MIAMI, Oct. 11 (AP)--The University of North Carolina whipped Miami's Hurricanes, 20--13, tonight. The big, agile Tar Heel line thwarted five Miami scoring thrusts before a crowd of 47,166 in the Orange Bowl.

Coffee futures rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices were influenced principally by Brazilian buying in the near-by positions. Final prices were up 15 to 93 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 62,250 bags.
A lawyer for the owners of a disputed Long Island bank building yesterday challenged the legality of the incorporation of the village of Lindenhurst.
HAVANA, Oct. 11 (AP)--A court-martial today sentenced seventeen officers of Cuba's armed forces to serve one to six years in prison for rebellion against President Fulgencio Batista's Government.
MOSCOW, Oct. 11 (UP)--SoViet scientists are working on a project designed to send space ships to the moon "in one day," a physicist said today.
Mayor Wagner was described last night by his Republican opponent in this year's mayoral election as a specialist in broken promises.

LONDON, Oct. 11--In a farewell gesture of royal courtesy, Queen Elizabeth II gave a dinner party tonight for officials and diplomats who would otherwise have had to rise before dawn tomorrow to take leave of the Queen at London Airport.

The New York City Opera introduced an Italian conductor to this country last night when it presented its third production of the season. The opera was Verdi's "La Traviata" and the man who led it with remarkable sensitivity was Arturo Basile.

FUCHU, Japan, Oct. 11--Our military relationships with Japan are based on paradox. We imposed upon this defeated former enemy a Constitution forbidding all armed forces. By law the Japanese cannot fight even a defensive war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11-- President Eisenhower cheered for the losing team tonight as the United States Air Force Academy lost to George Washington University, 20 to 0.

These jobs deal with continuing and long-range problems--national defense, foreign aid, atomic energy. They demand men of high talent, ingenuity and determination to foster and administer the programs by which the Administration stands or falls.

A TALE is told of Queen Elizabeth's great-great grandmother, As a young Queen, secure in her first wide popularity and the radiant wife of an adored Prince Consort, Victoria overheard a lady-in-waiting call a friend of hers "happy as a queen." Then the woman stopped in some embarrassment. But Queen Victoria exclaimed impulsively: "You are right. A Queen is a very happy woman!"

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12--The glamour, the drama and the appeal of the ArmyNotre Dame football game never seem to diminish. The ancient series was resurrected today after a lapse of ten years and it was the same glorious spectacle it always had been. It also was a whale of a game.

Registration of voters for next month's mayoral election ended last night with an unexpected surge in the number of registrants. The total exceeded the number of voters who qualified for the last municipal election, in 1953.

Miss Rand makes no secret of her thoughts on morality, government, justice, business, do-gooders or the doctrine of original sin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 (UP)--The baseball Giants officially went into business in San Francisco today. The first thing President Horace Stoneham did was to purchase the Pacific Coast League franchise of the Seals from the Boston Red Sox.

WESTBURY, L .I., Oct. 15-- The J. P. Farm's Grand R. Volo from Yonkers went the entire mile on the outside to score a half-length victory over Hillsota in the Queens Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The time was 2:01 4-5.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15--Arab and Asian nations were reported today to be considering placing the border dispute between Syria and Turkey before the General Assembly.
Mayor Wagner made a bid for tenants' support last night by pledging himself to fight for the continuance of rent control in New York City.

Reino Hayhanen, a confessed Soviet spy, testified in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that on two occasions he had been ordered to arrange for the payment of $5,000 to Mrs. Helen Sobell, wife of Morton Sobell, a convicted spy.
LONDON, Oct. 15--Britain earned a surplus of 211,000,000 ($590,800,000) in her dealings with the hest of the world during the year ended last June 30.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 15--Queen Elizabeth II of Britain will see many pleasant reminders of home when she tours this city and near-by Jamestown tomorrow. Both places were colonized by brave Englishmen for their sovereigns in the seventeenth century.
OTTAWA, Oct. 15--Queen Elizabeth II visited French Canada today and received a spirited and warm reception from thousands of flag-waving inhabitants.
GROTON, Mass., Oct. 15-- Students at Groton enjoyed a holiday from classes today in observance of the school's seventy-third birthday.

Robert Moses took issue yesterday with "a strange succession of vociferous enemies" on the Niagara "frontier," and warned some of them that they may "add millions" to the cost of the upstate power project.
DEARSORN, Mich., Oct. 15 --A major policy shift that will result in virtually an all-new car each year was announced today by the Ford Motor Company.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night endorsed the qualifications of thirty-five judicial candidates who are contending for a total of twenty-one posts.
BUFFALO, Oct. 15--A former Defense Department official charged today that Charles E. Wilson was largely responsible for the lag in the United States earth satellite program.
The International Longshoremen's Association and its fastest growing local have ended their feud and turned their attention back to the organizing of steamship office workers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 --Arthur Lubin, motion-picture director, and Mitchell Hamilburg, Hollywood artists' agent, have formed a partnership to produce a half-hour television series.

A new car line, the Ambassador series, was presented yesterday by the American Motors Corporation. The new models, which will go on display next Tuesday, replace the company's discontinued Nash and Hudson lines. Prices start at $2,587.

WUHAN, China, Oct. 15 (Reuters)--Crowds cheered, firecrackers exploded and sirens wailed here today as a new mile-long road and rail bridge linking north and south China opened to traffic across the Yangtze river.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 15--The Indian Communist party adopted today a resolution demanding the dismissal of Finance Minister T.T. Krishnamachari.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15--The Arab nations have been forced into economic warfare with Israel as "the only measure with which they could defend themselves," an Arab spokesman asserted today.

To each of the thirty members of the Milwaukee Braves who was voted a full share, the recent world series victory was worth $8,924.36. The beaten New York Yankees, with thirtythree full shares, had to be content with $5,606.06.

IT probably will be the last sports event ever held at the Polo Grounds. The most famous of baseball arenas will close on Sunday with international matches in hurling and Gaelic football. The relief captain of the Norwegian freighter Belleville, which ran aground off Newport, R.I., on Sept. 24, yesterday placed the blame for the accident on the pilot.

History repeated itself this week when the nation's sports writers and broadcasters again placed Michigan State ahead of Oklahoma as the nation's No. 1 college football team in the weekly Associated Press poll.

An economist has coined a phrase to describe the influence of Sputnik on United States defense expenditures. Dr. Harold M. Somers told a State Bar Association meeting in Buffalo the other day that it was a "controlled panic."

A long feud between Michael J. Quill and the leadership of Philadelphia Local 234 of the Transport Workers Union reached the showdown stage yesterday.

JORGE BOLET has always been a gifted pianist. He is now becoming a major figure both as virtuoso and musician. It is time he received full recognition for his accomplishments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16--President Eisenhower announced today a change of command over the United States Information Agency, which directs this country's overseas information activities.

Of the six constitutional amendments proposed to the voters of New York for action on Nov. 5 the authorization of $250,000,000 in bond issue borrowing for expansion of the State University is No. 1 in position on the voting machine and No. 1 in importance.
Continued fair and mild weather has resulted in further abatement of the Asian influenza epidemic in the city.

Mrs. Marion Abt Bachrach of 51 Charles Street, public relations director of the Communist party of the United States from 1947 to 1951, died yesterday of cancer at Manhattan General Hospital. Her age was 57.

PARIS, Oct. 16--A British spokesman told Europeans today that Britain would not abandon tariff protection of her agriculture in the interest of the European free trade zone she had proposed. But he suggested seeking agreements for cooperation for freer trade in farm products.

A $60,170,250 order for 19,737 1958 automobiles has been placed by the Hertz Rent a Car System, Inc., Walter L. Jacobs, president, announced yesterday. He said it was the largest single purchase of new automobiles in history.
Directors of the Vick Chemical Company yesterday raised its cash dividend by 33 1/3 per cent. through a combination of a 5-for-4 stock split and an increased quarterly dividend rate.

Passenger operations by American railroads suffered a grievous blow last month. They were walloped by one of the dullest blunt instruments ever wielded, the publication of a pound and three-quarters of statistical study entitled "Avoidable Costs of Passenger Train Service."

Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji broke his own track record in winning the Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase by seven lengths at Belmont Park yesterday.

The defense in the trial of Rudolf Ivanovich Abel asked District Judge Mortimer W. Byers yesterday to order the Government to produce certain data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Abel has been indicted as a Soviet master spy.

Next Monday, Lawrence Langner will leave for London where he will attempt to expedite matters for the presentation on Broadway this season of "Summer of the 17th Doll." This is the Australian comedy by Ray Lawler that has found especial favor with the London theatre world.
PARIS, Oct. 16--As France struggled to end her political crisis, her economic life was slowed to a virtual standstill today by a massive strike of gas and electricity workers.

WASHINGTON, Oct 17 (UP) --A committee of the InterAmerican Press Association warned dictators in the Western Hemisphere today that press censorship could result in their downfall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 741,520 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Savings banks in New York State, with 60 per cent of the assets of all savings banks in the country, must take the initiative if the mutual savings banking system is to be extended on a nation-wide basis, a Brooklyn savings bank trustee asserted yesterday.

Newly added to the ramified agenda of the American National Theatre and Academy is the development of future theatregoers from the ranks of high school and college students. At a price within their means, tickets will be distributed at 50 cents each.

Eighteen thousand persons attended a "birthday party" at Madison Square Garden last night. As if to prove the point, the Eighth Avenue marquee of the Garden bore the illuminated inscription "A Little Private Party Tonight."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 17 --President Iskander Mirza asked the Moslem League today to form a coalition government. It was the Moslem League that created an independent Pakistan and then slid to the verge of political oblivion.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company plans to borrow $60,000,000 in the public bond market in December, or early next year. The money will be raised on first mortgage bonds to be sold at competitive bidding, the company said.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct 17--Nationalist China charged the Soviet Union today with consistent blocking of world moves toward disarmament.

The ex-world champion Yankees, who do not care for the "ex," yesterday moved to guarantee its removal. George Weiss, the general manager of the Bombers, announced the purchase of four top minor league players who will appear on the Yankee list for the first time.

North American production of newsprint in September fell below the record set in September, 1956, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.

Business loans outstanding in the seventeen larger New York City banks increased $13,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday points lower to 6 points higher than on Wednesday.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 17 (AP)--Aly Khan's Rose Royale II shot to the front in the last quarter and raced to a sixlength victory in the mile and a quarter Champion Stakes today.

She was only one of many now nameless ships that plied the Mediterranean during the busy days of the early Roman Empire.

It is now clear that Nikita S. Khrushchev miscalculated badly when he tried to win over the chief Western European Socialist parties to the fantastic Soviet line on the Middle East. Wool prices soared yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The rise was one of the sharpest of the year. Tops advanced 4.2 to 4.9 cents a pound and grease wool gained 3.7 to 6 cents. Volume was moderately heavy.

TWO moods emerge in Janice Biala's exhibition at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue. One derives from the abundant excitement of bullfights. Miss Biala has resumed this subject since her last show, only this time her image is far more concentrated and liberated from descriptive detail.

If welcoming crowds in this city could be measured like earthquakes, the reception accorded to Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip yesterday would have to be classed as one of the lesser ones.

BUFFALO, Oct. 21--United States industry, long a financial friend of technical colleges, is showing increased interest in liberal arts institutions, according to Dr. Eugene W. Bewkes, president of St. Lawrence University.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2l --On the eve of her gayest national holiday, India is faced with one of the most serious troubles in her grim treasury of problems--food shortages.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--The United States welcomed today King Saud's offer to mediate between Turkey and Syria as a move that could no do harm and might do some good.
WARSAW, Oct. 21--The arts and sciences, which wrenched themselves free from politics during Poland's upheaval last year, are to be reharnessed to the Communist party line.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--The International Brotherhood of Teamsters asked today for an early trial of the challenge of James R. Hoffa's election as president.
Prince Philip found time in his busy schedule yesterday to present a medal to one of America's pioneer nuclear physicists and to pay his respects to the nation's scientists in general.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21--Clayton R. Burt, former president of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company, manufacturer of industrial tools, now known as the Pratt Whitney Company, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 21--Robert A. Gibney, chairman of the board and treasurer of J.C. Bull, Inc., an advertising agency at 101 Parks Avenue, New York, died here today in his home at 640 Ely Avenue. His age was 68.
TOKYO, Oct. 21 (AP)--Golfers practicing for the international Canada Cup matches this week are being introduced to the Kasumigaseki Country Club course by girl caddies.
Mayor Wagner appealed for the re-election of Council President Abe Stark before two audiences in Brooklyn yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP)--The nose cone of the Soviet rocket-satellite may be starting to disintegrate, a scientist said here tonight.
Prince Philip became a pedestrian in mid-Manhattan in the rush hour yesterday without being recognized.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21-- An air pollution expert said today that the pollution nuisance could be avoided by intelligent community planning, based on accurate scientific data.
PARIS, Oct. 21--Outlines of a compromise to end France's three-week-old Government crisis took shape tonight.
LONDON, Oct. 21--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will take one of Britain's leading authorities on atomic power with him for his talks with President Eisenhower in Washington.

In the opinion of Queen Elizabeth, "a visit to New York for just a day is really a teaser." Britain's young Queen was so quoted late yesterday while looking at what she called a "tremendous" and "beautiful" view from the 102-story Empire State Building.
The Extension Division of the City College School of General Studies will open an adult education branch next March in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Oct. 21-- Art Altomaro of the Greenwich Country Club repeated as Westchester-Fairfield Caddiemasters' Association champion today by scoring 36, 38--74 over the Fairview Country Club's par-72 course. The card was marked by five birdies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--The Senate's steel-pricing inquiry turned today to an examination of the salaries and bonuses paid to top executives of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
A picket line of four pier watchmen, set up at the Cunard Line's Pier 92 yesterday, halted longshore operations at the West Fifty-second Street terminal. The dock workers refused to cross the line.

BUSY hostesses will welcome two new seasoning mixes, especially created by the House of Herbs, Inc., Salisbury, Conn.. for those who like the hard work done for them. One, labeled Angel Dip Mix, gives a delicate herb flavor when blended with cream cheese for cocktail spreads.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21-- The volume of wholesale hardware sales was down 2 per cent for the first nine months this year compared with the same period in 1956, members of the National Wholesale Hardware Association heard today.
New sunshade and awning designs and improved fabrics were displayed yesterday at the Commodore Hotel at the fortyfourth annual convention of the Canvas Products Association International.
Magnetic tape for recording and reproducing color television pictures was demonstrated here yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- President Eisenhower appealed today for expanded people-to-people programs to promote international understanding and world peace.

ROME, Oct. 21--Italy's small but important Right-wing Socialist party reaffirmed its loyalty to the Atlantic alliance today.

Francis Sydney Bancroft, chairman of the board and former president of the Excelsior Savings Bank, died yesterday in his office at the bank at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street. He was 76 years old.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21--The Soviet Government denied today that it was massing troops on the Turkish border.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--Corporate profits declined noticeably in the second quarter of this year, compared with the first quarter, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Latin-American coffee producing countries have announced a plan to strengthen coffee prices.
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in successive waves of selling on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the biggest break since President Eisenhower's heart attack in September, 1955.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 (AP)--Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz maintained today that he had taken the initiative in speeding payment of claims for land appropriated for highway use.

A challenge to the legality of a special grand jury investigating charges of official corruption and wrongdoing in Suffolk County was rejected late yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

Raimund von Hofmannsthal of London has announced here the engagement of his daughter, Miss Romana von Hofmannsthal of New York, to Rory McEwen of Berwickshire, Scotland. He is the son of Sir John and Lady McEwen of Berwickshire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--A senior Democrat on the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee predicted today that the Soviet Union would "score another psychological triumph" by flying a nuclear-powered plane before the United States did.

Benjamin E. Neal, founder of I Am An American Day, observed annually on the third Sunday in May, and of the Good Neighbor Foundation, died on Thursday in the Veterans Administration Hospital at First Avenue and Twenty-third Street. His age was 66.

The shape of things to come this week in intercollegiate football is different from what appeared in prospect prior to the wholesale wrecking operations of last' Saturday.

WHEN Frank Lane was the general manager of the Chicago White Sox, he plunged into a rather violent feud with Charles Dillon Stengel. Not many men in baseball care to challenge Ol' Case to a duel of words. The words that Stengel uses are the sharpest ever honed.

As soon as a batter hits a home run, the angry pitcher throws a fast ball at the head of the next hitter. This is akin to teaching a lesson to the innocent bystander while the real transgressor escapes.
The nation's mutual funds sought yesterday to back up with statistics their often repeated boast that they lend stability to a declining stock market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23--The Defense Department announced tonight that the Air Force had successfully fired a rocket designed to go up 4,000 miles. Detailed results of the launching and the distance achieved will not be known until the "extensive data obtained" are analyzed.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23-- Gov. Abrabam A. Ribicoff had a preview today of the new $464,000,000 Connecticut Turnpike. He pronounced it "magnificent."

Counsel for the defense in the espionage trial of Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel rested their case in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday without calling any witnesses. The defendant himself decided not to testify.
MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 23-- The United States alone has the power to hold the free world together against the threat of communism, Dean Acheson said tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) --Thirty members of the frontoffice family of the Los Angeles Dodgers, headed by President Walter F. O'Malley, received a tumultuous reception when their private plane landed at International Airport tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23--Canada appealed to the big powers today for "at least a beginning in actual measures of disarmament."
WINDHAM, N.Y., Oct. 23-- Elephant fever was spreading today across two upstate counties, luring scores of men, women and children into the only elephant hunt anyone here can remember.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 23--The Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Knubel of 43 Rockland Place, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York and New England, died of a heart ailment last night in New Rochelle Hospital. His age was 60.
Stocks of light heating oils rose again to a new high last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 23-- A nation-wide plebiscite will probably be conducted in 1959 among members of the Universalist and Unitarian Churches on the eventual merger of the two bodies.
NEWARK, Oct. 23--John R. Cooney, former president of the Loyalty Group, an association of insurance companies, has been indicted with two other individuals and a concern on charges of conspiracy.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 23 (AP)--Syria kept the Turkish issue boiling today. In effect she accused the United States Sixth Fleet of sending planes deep over her territory.
Six racket-infested locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in this city were still doing business as usual yesterday, despite the appointment of a trustee by the parent union Oct. 15.

Jamaica furnished its answer to the sputnik in the form of Atom Rocket, second half of a hear-record daily double of $2,556 yesterday. Betty Sechrest's 3-year-old reached the winner's orbit by a neck to return $81.40, $28.60 and $15 across the board, with Paul J. Bailey riding.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 23-- Taking the lead at the halfway mark, Prudence's Boy scored an easy length-and-three-quarter triumph in the $3,400 Bridgeport Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 23--A Nassau-Suffolk industrial commission, to be operated jointly by the two county governments, was proposed here today as the first step toward long-range stabilization of Long Island factory employment.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 23 --Nine Negro students attending Central High School walked out of the school after classes today without a military escort.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., Oct. 23-- The chief of the Federal Children's Bureau declared here tonight that working mothers could not be charged with the rise in juvenile delinquency. No studies yet have proved any connection between the two developments, Mrs. Katherine Brownell Oettinger said.

Xavier Cugat, bandleader and a Leading exponent of LatinAmerican rhythms, has been engaged for the featured role of the first mate in "The Captain's Paradise." This will be his first acting assignment on Broadway.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 23-- President Ngo Dinh Diem accused "Communist saboteurs" today of responsibility for the bombings here yesterday directed at United States service personnel and property.
MONTECATINI, Italy, Thursday, Oct. 24--Christian Dior, for many years the leader in the world of fashion design, died here early today of a heart attack. His age was 52.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23-- Pennsylvania has yet to achieve its first victory of the 1957 football season, but Coach Steve Sebo maintains in the most affirmative terms that it is a better team than the 1956 varsity.

Mrs. Hazel Sharper, for whom Deputy Police Commissioner Robert J. Mangum allegedly interceded to erase an arrest for disorderly conduct, appeared late yesterday in Traffic Court with her husband, Ralph.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23--A high and perhaps increased incidence of Asian influenza will continue for eight or ten weeks, at which time a decline is expected, the Public Health Service said today.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh observed her tenth anniversary as president of Barnard College yesterday afternoon with "the nicest kind of party--a family party." In fact, she made her appearance at the occasion only on a no-fuss basis.
Mayor Wagner, in an appeal for both labor and business votes, emphasized last night the efforts his Administration was making to reduce labor strife and promote business.

A court ruling with far-reaching implications for advertising has been handed down in Philadelphia.

SAIGON, Oct. 23--During each of the last four years expenditures on development in free countries of South and Southeast Asia have risen about 20 per cent. Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister of External Affairs, told Colombo Plan delegates today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP)--The stock market upsurge was reflected in grain trading today.
Total fatalities involved in railroad accidents in 1956 set a new low record. This was revealed at the annual Harriman Award Dinner sponsored by the American Museum of Safety.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 23--The Nobel Prize in Medicine for 1957 will be awarded tomorrow to Dr. Daniel Bovet, head of the Pharmacology Department of the Italian Health Institute in Rome, it was learned today.
New issues of debt and equity securities of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire-- $8,000,000 of mortgage bonds and $3,943,000 of common stock --are being offered to investors today.

The 1958 Plymouth is basically unchanged in style from the 1957 model. Ornamental trim has been altered and other innovations have been incorporated to give the car a fresh look. A new line of engines, some of them optional at extra cost, will be available.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 23 (AP)--The Vanguard rocket, which is expected to project a United States artificial moon, went through another successful test today, rising 109 miles.
LONDON, Oct. 23--The Labor party told Nikita S. Khrushchev today that it was not prepared "to undertake joint activities with any Communist party."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) --The Los Angeles Dodgers tonight made formal what already had been anticipated--the signing of contracts for 1958 by Manager Walt Alston and Harold (Pee Wee) Reese, the team captain.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York plans a continuing evangelism campaign that will operate from offices near Times Square on a budget of about $1,000,000 a year.

Honors and rewards are going in rapid succession to a Jersey yachtsman, Dr. Anson G. Hoyt of Rumson, and Red Bank. Last night he was elected commodore of the Eastern Cruiser Association. This makes him the top figure in predicted log contests in these parts.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 24 --Ten homes on the western slopes of the Palisades will be opened Wednesday for an afternoon tour of Thanksgiving dining rooms. It will be a benefit for the Women's Association of the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--The president of the Service Pipe Line Company denounced today charges that it had deliberately violated an antitrust consent decree.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20-- West Germany added about 6,500 men to its armed forces last week and increased the total strength to about 118,000 men.

Platinum is in a slump. First signs came in July when Baker Co., Inc. major platinum dealer in this country, trimmed the price $9 an ounce to $84 in July. The high for the year had been $105 an ounce.
Election of Donald W. Douglas Jr., 40 years old, as president of the giant Douglas Aircraft Company was announced yesterday.

KASUMIGASEKI, Japan, Friday, Oct. 25 (AP)--Sam Snead fell victim to one of his famous blow-ups, skying to a two-over par 74, and the Japanese forged to a two-stroke lead over the United States today after the second round of the International Canada Cup golf competition.
Twelve million persons in the metropolitan area got a reprieve yesterday from the threat of a milk strike.

Member banks in the nation operated under substantially easier reserve positions in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WINDHAM, N.Y., Oct. 24-- The festive spirit that had marked the elephant hunt in these parts for seven days was washed away today by rain and a feeling of discouragement.
Stocks went through another day of violent swings yesterday and ended on a note of uncertainty. Prices at the close were a little higher, but falling.

IPSWICH, England, Oct. 24 --The Labor party won a smashing victory in a Parliamentary by-election here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24-- Edgar H. Dixon testified in court today that he had always regarded the Dixon-Yates contract as an "awkward way" for the Administration to carry out its policy of curbing further expansion of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Contemporary American paintings and sculpture at last have a home of their own in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Efforts are under way to form a centrist-rightist coalition for Argentina's Presidential election next Feb. 23. One aim is to attract labor union members who once followed the deposed President, Juan D. Peron.

Gale Kerwin, a 22-year-old Canadian now residing in Valley Stream, L.I., will oppose Johnny Busso, a lightweight contender from New York, in the ten-round feature at Madison Square Garden tonight. WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)-- Former United States Senator Herman Welker of Idaho was described as in critical condition at the National Institutes of Health tonight after undergoing brain surgery.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 28 --Security forces used batons and tear gas here today to disperse demonstrators following Oxi Day celebrations. Oxi Day marks Greece's entry into World War II on the side of the Allies.
Two labor unions were involved in a dispute yesterday. One union employs members of the other. One of the major issues was: Is there a contract?
A testimonial dinner given for the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham by the Protestant Council last night marked the conclusion of the evangelist's New York Crusade.
At the close of trading yesterday prices on the New York Stock Exchange were almost exactly where they had been before last week's convolutions began. The loss for the month so far was 6 per cent.

Six strangers from the animal world exchanged glances yesterday with sixty children at the Henry Street Settlement. The fuzzy visitors were from the cast of the Festival of Pets to be seen at the New York Coliseum for four days starting Nov. 21.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 (Reuters)--The Swedish Air Force announced today that Sweden had produced a guided missile to be used by fighter planes. Details were not disclosed.

The Flushing area placement office of the State Department of Labor in Queens was damaged considerably by fire yesterday.
A union president praised shoe manufacturers yesterday for raising prices, but complained that the increases were not big enough.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)-- The Seventh-Day Adventist Church announced today a record 1958 world budget of $26,064,954. The budget was approved at the final meeting of the denomination's autumn council. It represents more than a 15 per cent increase over the 1957 budget.

Louis Hamburger, a retired textile manufacturer, died Sunday in a New York nursing home after a long illness. His age was 89, and he had formerly lived in Brooklyn and New Rochelle, N.Y.

The International Geophysical Year was the subject of the first of a new series of educational telecasts presented last night by the National Broadcasting Company.

PARIS, Oct. 28 (U.P.)--Algerian gunmen shot and killed a former deputy Mayor of Algiers outside a Paris subway station today. The former official, Hocine Cherchalli, 28 years old, father of two children, had been in France for two years and was working for an insurance company.
The town of West New York, N.J., has become the first community in the metropolitan area to obtain a pledge of Federal aid for a low-rent apartment house designed for the aged.

The child, who will be named Amy Jo, is a grandaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Wishnick of New York.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press)--Senator Sarto Fournier was elected today Mayor of Montreal for a threeyear term, defeating the incumbent, Jean Drapeau in one of the closest elections in years.

An editorial in Pravda yesterday stressing the primacy of the Communist party over the armed forces appears to repeat a theme that has been reiterated in Soviet service newspapers in the last two weeks.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 28-- With the last of the ballots in yesterday's election still to be counted, the incumbent Democratic party today had a big majority in the 610-seat Grand National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) --The State Department ruled today that a protocol aide, Victor Purse, had exercised "bad judgment" in accepting a gift automobile from King Saud of Saudi Arabia.

Mrs. Lillian R. Clark of 801 West-End Avenue, who was on the New York County and Federal Grand Jury for many years, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital. Her age was 70. She was the widow of Albert Clark, a manufacturer, who died in 1912.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 28-- State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, Republican candidate for Governor, said tonight that the way the State Raffles and Bingo Act was being administered "is subiect to review."
LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP)--Four American entertainers--Judy Garland, Count Basie, Mario Lanza and Ben Lyon--were invited to appear before Queen Elizabeth II at this year's Royal Variety Performance.
DAMASCUS, Oct. 28--Syria and the Soviet Union signed today a twelve-year economic and technical assistance agreement.
OVIEDO, Spain, Oct. 28 (AP)-- A powder factory less than two miles from Oviedo exploded today. At least seven persons perished.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) --The University of Pennsylvania said today that no one would be allowed to drink liquor at its home football games.
Mayor Wagner swore in Carl M. Loeb Jr. yesterday as chairman of the recently created Board of Correction. Mr. Loeb, 53 years old, is married and lives at 895 Park Avenue.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 28 --The Army-Utah football game at Michie Stadium Nov. 9 has been sold out, Col. E.W. Amick, the business manager of athletics, said today. Some 16,000 boys from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will see the games as part of the annual Boy Scouts Day.

ALBANY Oct. 28 (AP)--The State Board of Regents ruled today that it lacked power to review a decision by the State Education Commissioner barring a Long Island school district from posting the Ten Commandments in its classrooms.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) --Gen. Lauris Norstad said today that any nation starting a war against the West would be destroyed.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP)--The Soviet Union's earth satellite and its rocket have not been seen for the last three days.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 28 (UP)--Burmese army units were reported today to have routed a band of fifty Chinese Kuomintang soldiers in an action Oct. 3 in the China-Burma border area, killing one and capturing supplies and equipment. The band was part of the Nationalist forces that fled south during the Communist takeover in China in 1949 and have operated since then in the border area.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 28-- Lay-offs in two North Jersey industries are contributing to an employment problem in this area that the manager of the state's employment bureau here says "could become critical."
Profits of the Aluminum Company of America increased in the third quarter this year compared with those of the same period a year ago, when operations were affected by an industry wide strike.

The Federal Government is proceeding with plans to develop a second type of nuclear propulsion for merchant ships. It will be created by a nuclear gas turbine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (U.P.) --Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, said today the "waste" in the foreign aid program could provide funds for the Upper Colorado water conservation project.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 --William M. Dozier will return to the Columbia Broadcasting System next month as a generalprograming executive in charge of all live shows here.

EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 28 (AP)-- Gloria Haley, actress, and her husband, Louis (Buddy) Bregman, music arranger, obtained a mutual consent divorce in Juarez, Mexico, last Monday, the First Civil Court in Juarez reported today.
