ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 29 (AP)--Two brief earth tremors shook Asuncion shortly after noon today. No injuries or damages were reported.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 29 (AP) --Military officials announced today that Chinese Nationalist forces in the Matsu Islands had carried, out twenty-four patrol missions on Communist China's mainland in the last six months.
CAIRO, Oct. 29--President Gamal Abdel Nasser said today that Egypt felt no spite or rancor against those who attacked her a year ago over the Suez Canal crisis.
BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 29 (UP)--Roy Emerson and Ashley Cooper were tied at two sets each today when darkness halted play in the quarter-finals of the Queensland tennis championship.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 29 (AP)-- The Bolivian Government today declared a nation-wide state of siege, a form of martial law, because of disturbances in oil fields in Santa Cruz Province.

The new fabrics coming up for spring show many different faces. Patterns range from floral prints on silk chiffon, linen and cotton to crisp haberdasher types such as checks, glen plaids and stripes on lightweight wools, silks or cottons.
OGDEN, Utah, Oct. 29 (AP)-- Modern radar requires such tremendous power that it has become a hazard, an Air Force radiation expert said today.
The election of Rudolph Cubicciotti as president of the National Lubricating Grease Institute was announced yesterday by the board of directors.
SAINT--NAZAIRE, France, Oct. 29 (Reuters)--Ten thousand shipbuilding workers decided to return to their jobs .....
The rocket that thrust the Soviet earth satellite into its orbit gained an entire lap on the sphere yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 29 (AP) --Navy's football team skipped its customary scrimmage today because of injuries and concentrated on lighter work for Saturday's game at Notre Dame.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 29--Increasingly severe teacher short ages will plague New York in the proposed $250,000,000 State University bond issue is not approved, the incoming president of the State School Boards Association said here today.

Horace Stoneham and Charles S. Feeney, the president and vice president, respectively, of the San Francisco Giants, returned to San Francisco by plane last night. The baseball executives had been here "straightening out things" for the past several days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) --George Meany, president of the labor federation, took up with President Eisenhower today a grievance against the Taft-Hartley Act.
Mrs. Hazel Sharper was fined $200 yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh on her plea of guilty to four traffic violations. Mrs. Sharper, 38 years old, of 676 River- .....
A special local preview of the 1958 cars of the Chrysler Corporation was staged yesterday at the Chrysler International Automobile Salon, Lexington Avenue and East Forty-second Street.

Andrew P. Maloney, an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company since he joined the bank in 1950, has been named a vice president. He will be in charge of the bank's office at Third Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, which will open next spring.

A hearing on contempt charges against Marie Torre, television columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, was adjourned in Federal Court yesterday until tomorrow. Miss Torre has been ordered to show cause why she should not be held in contempt for refusing to reveal sources of information for a story she wrote about Judy Garland, the actress.

Thirteen trains of the Long Island Rail Road were delayed yesterday when a train struck a dump truck at a crossing in Springfield Gardens, Queens. No one was injured. The train was bound from Far Rockaway to Pennsylvania Station.

Francis W.H. Adams, John S. Linen, Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr. and Bethuel M. Webster have been elected trustees of the Institute of Public Ad ministration.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29--With a show of good humor and confidence, Nikita S. Khrushchev declared tonight that Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov would soon get another job, a job for which he was "experienced and qualified."

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 29 (AP)--An investigator said today that the Northeast Airlines DC-3 that crashed here Sept. 15 with a loss of twelve lives had had trouble landing at Martha's Vineyard airport, the last stop before the accident.

The Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation announced yesterday that its national office had been moved to the Coliseum Tower Building, 10 Columbus Circle, New York 19. It previously was at 23 West Fortyfifth Street. The telephone number remains PLaza 7-7633.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 30 (AP)--Japan said today it had successfully tested the first Japan-made supersonic rocket seven times this month.

Mayor Wagner last night assailed his Republican opposition for "irresponsible, defamatory charges" that he said were refuted by his Administration's record of achievement.

Taking the position that if you can't fight Dan Cupid, you can educate those hit by his darts, the U.S.O. has called on clergymen and social workers to help with a program of "preparation for marriage."
An assertion by Governor Harriman's chief counsel that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was trying to usurp the powers of the State Banking Department was answered by Mr. Lefkowitz yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 29 (AP)--The newspaper Indonesia Raya resumed publication today after having been closed twelve days by local military authorities.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 29 (AP)-- William Marshall Bullitt, former United States Solicitor General, left the bulk of his estate, estimated at $1,500,000, to his widow, Mrs. Nora I. Bullitt.
ALBANY, Oct. 29--School districts will not lose state aid because of Asian influenza after all.
Peter Ustinov's comedy "Romanoff and Juliet" will give three matinees during Thanksgiving week, on Nov. 27, 28 and 30.

Robert E. Gottschalk, president of Panavision, Inc., announced yesterday the formation of Panavision Films to make feature motion pictures in the new wide-screen process. Panavasion is an anamorphic system, using a 65 mm. negative ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Dr. Farley Acree, an outstanding organic chemistry researcher, died last Wednesday after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Oct. 29 (UP)--A four-motored Air Force KC97 tanker plane crashed into a 6,500-foot mountain forty miles north of here today, killing at least eight of the sixteen crewmen believed aboard. The other crewmen were unaccounted for.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 29 (UP) --A Baptist minister said today that "three press associations, four radio and three television networks" now dominate the thinking of Americans once influenced by ministers and educators.

Only two counties, New York and Kings, are electing District Attorneys this year and the voters really have no alternative even if they were looking for one. Both candidates to succeed themselves have the endorsement of all major political parties.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)--At tempt, a 7-2 shot ridden by Tony Skoronski, led all the way to capture the feature at Sportsman's Park today.
Fire and an explosion in the garment center yesterday afternoon drove dozens of workers to the streets in panic and badly snarled traffic in mid-Manhattan.

In the hope of recapturing the leadership in automotive sales, the 1958 Chevrolet has been drastically restyled and re-engineered at a reported cost of more than $300,000,000. The cars will go on sale tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--The nuclear age produced another new term today. The country's first atomic-powered merchant ship will carry the designation NS (for nuclear ship) instead of the familiar SS (for steamship).

The Transit Authority will begin a test today of the adage that time is money. It will provide subway-goers with a new clock system combined with advertising from which the Authority hopes eventually to realize an annual revenue of at least $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) --The Army announced today that the Ninth Infantry Division would begin reorganizing along "pentomic" lines Dec. 1, the last of fifteen divisions to be converted for atomic warfare.

Gimbels' fourth floor lingerie department has just unwrapped a new collection of M.C. Schrank bedtime outfits, ranging from a floor-length flannelette "Granny" gown for $5.98 to an equally covered-up bibfront night dress called "Queen Anne's Lace" that costs $12.98.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Oct. 28--An Antarctic mountain range probably extends beyond its present mapped position, it was reported today by Capt. Finn Ronne.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 29 --After ten years in hiding, the leader of Brazil's Communist party is reported to be planning to come into the open if a warrant for his arrest is canceled.
Sales and profits of the United States Steel Corporation for the first nine months this year reached new highs. The thirdquarter results also were the best for any such period.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 29 (AP)--Queen Elizabeth II's Doutelle today won the mile and a quarter Limekiln Stakes by three-quarter of a length from Rose Argent.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 29-- The Greenport Pace, the feature event at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, was won by Meadow Dream, J.E. Armstrong's 4-year-old bay horse. Driven by James Arthur, Meadow Dream took the $3,400 mile race by three-quarters of a length over Prince Eton.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was asked today to prepare a study of the possible effects of the European common market on the non-selfgoverning territories.

Coty has developed a mutation of fragrance oils that is defined as "not a cologne, not a perfume, not a toilet water." This formula has 'been made captive in a long-necked aerosol bottle with a gold cap.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 29 (UP) --A United States Army courtmartial convicted Specialist Raymond L. Bailey of Brownsburg, Ind., today of negligent homicide in the shooting of a Korean boy.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Oct. 29-- Leaders of the Algerian nationalist rebellion are as optimistic about their fighting chances as the French are confident of strangling the nationalist guerrilla movement.

Stepinac's Tom Dempsey captured his sixth straight race of the season and Mount St. Michael took the team title yesterday in the twenty-fourth annual cross-country championships of the Catholic high school's Bronx-Manhattan division.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--The chairman of the Senate Interior Committee charged today that President Eisenhower and his Administration were "sabotaging" the American mining of minerals vital to defense.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 29-- Congress annulled today the Oct. 20 Presidential election on the basis of "proven frauds." No date was set for new elections.
Two new varnish sprays have been introduced by Krylon, Inc. One has a high gloss, the other a satin finish. Both come in push button aerosol cans. The varnishes are designed for use indoors or out.
HARTFORD, Oct. 29--Meade Alcorn, Republican national Chairman, said today that the formation of a third party in the South was "inevitable."

W. Mahlon Dickerson of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and Everett B. Morris of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club became heads of the organizations that run sailing regattas on Long Island Sound yesterday.
The 1958 Buicks went on sale here yesterday. As expected, dealers' delivered prices were up from 2 to 6 per cent, depending on the model.
The Travelers Aid Society of New York yesterday opened its annual display in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal.

The outlook for persons with cancer of the head and neck has improved greatly in recent years, two scientists said yesterday. Their remarks were made at a press conference held at the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society.

Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., plans to redeem 4,204 shares of its 7 per cent preferred stock at $125 a share plus a fourthquarter dividend of $1.75 a share, Stock of record Nov. 25 will be called by lot on Nov. 26. The Manufacturers Trust Company is the redemption agent.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless. Wool, copper, zinc, lead, rubber and hides rose; cottonseed oil and potatoes declined, and price movements for cocoa, sugar and coffee were mixed.
Alexander Paul of Bethesda, Md., director of member relations for the Tax Foundation, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, was found dead yesterday in his room at the Conrad Hilton Hotel in Chicago.
Two men suspected of shooting and critically wounding a patrolman in the Bronx Thursday were arrested in Chicago last night.
By 1965 half the births in New York City hospitals will be babies born to indigent parents, physicians were told yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP)--Nearby wheat deliveries and all rye contracts rallied today to close a cent or more a bushel higher on the Board of Trade. Other futures ended steady.

Miss Margot Sari Hartman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Hartman of 912 Fifth Avenue and Stamford, Conn., was married here yesterday at noon to Delbert Tenney. He is the son of Mrs. Vivian Schmidt of Los Angeles and the adopted son of William Tenney of Los Angeles.

There's nothing like the tinkle of coins to arouse interest-- even in children. A new gift for youngsters that may start them on the collecting road is "The Star Coin Kit."

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday estimated for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, a record consolidated net income, of $660,000,000, or $3.33 on each of the 196,939,278 capital shares outstanding.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 29 (UP)--Trinity's football team, idle for more than two weeks because of the flu, was reported today to be nearly back to full strength. Coach Dan Jessee said that all flu cases had recovered and only two player's were on the injury list.
Thomas K. Finletter told the Fordham University Political Union yesterday that there was a "grave risk the United States will fall to defeat in the missiles program."

PHUOC LONG PROVINCE, Vietnam, Oct. 29--North Vietnam's armed forces have been built up to a strength of 450,000 to 500,000 men, President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam said here today in an interview.
A proposed $400,000,000 rapid transit link between New York and New Jersey was attacked yesterday by spokesmen for railroads, buses and business associations.
Assemblyman Walter H. Gladwin of 744 East 175th Street, the Bronx, was appointed a City Magistrate by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 29--President Tito of Yugoslavia will not take part in the Moscow celebration Nov. 7 marking the fortieth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

A few orchestra tickets are still available for the Nov. 18 performance of "Jamaica," proceeds of which will aid the Committee on Civil Rights in Manhattan, Inc. Lena Horne is star in the new musical opening at the Imperial Theatre on Thursday.

Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Treat of 1001 Park Avenue have made known the engagement of Mrs. Treat's daughter, Miss Joan Converse Herndon, to Morgan J. O'Brien 3d. He is the son of Mrs. Robert Z. Hawkins of Reno and the late State Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien of New York.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 29--Last summer, Bobby Bragan, then the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, caused considerable comment for continually changing his line-ups. At Mercersburg Academy, Chris Corkery, the new head coach of football, has been following the same practice.
LOREN WELCH, baritone, who has sung on Broad way in "Barefoot Boy with Cheek," "On the Town" and other musicals, made an appearance in recital at Town Hall last night.

THE most curious sports development of recent weeks, perhaps, is the rekindling of the romance between Charlie Dressen and the Dodgers. After years of chilly separation, they are about to go steady again. The talkative little egotist was named yesterday as coaching assistant to Walter Alston, the manager of the Brooks--Oops! Sorry--manager of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) --The Federal Power Commission has authorized the Northern States Power Company, Eau Claire, Wis., to acquire the facilities of the Wisconsin Hydro Electric Company, Amery, Wis. Wisconsin Hydro will be liquidated.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, one of the "big three" tobacco manufacturers, had record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, John C. Whitaker, chairman, and E.A. Darr, president, reported yesterday.
Miss Gloria Franceschini and Frank Osgood Butler 2d will be married Dec. 27 in San Francisco.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 (AP) --Charlie Dressen returned to the Dodgers as a coach today. He said emphatically that he had no ambitions to manage the club.

PARIS, Oct. 29 (Reuters)-- Two thousand fashion leaders today paid their final tributes to Christian Dior, creator of the "New Look" in women's apparel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--A key Republican Senator indirectly warned President Eisenhower today that his forthcoming decision on a tariff case could have an important effect on next year's reciprocal trade legislation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the latest Moscow mystery was probably symptornatic of serious political and economic tensions within the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29-- Secretary of State Dulles proposed today a redivision of military responsibilities among the free world's allies.
"Best of Burlesque," the week-end midnight bill at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse, will close Nov. 16.
Hoping to strengthen their second-place position in the National Hockey League, the New York Rangers will engage the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight at 7:30.

Recaptured from the movies after twenty-five years, the completely reconstructed Globe will become a legitimate house once more on Jan. 10. The restoration will be noted on that date by the presentation of "Much Ado About Nothing" for a limited stand.
Oklahoma's narrow escape against Colorado cost the Sooner eleven first place in the weekly Associated Press poll as Texas A. and M. took over the lead.
Ten-year-old Eddie Hodges, a featured cast member of Meredith Willson's forthcoming musical "The Music Man," has been elected Junior Gospel Singer of the Year by the American Gospel Singers.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 29-- Gov. Robert B. Meyner denounced today Republican charges that $30,000,000 to $40,000,000 could be saved by cutting out waste in the state government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) --Federal aid for school construction, twice turned down by Congress in the last two years, has been quietly ticketed for a House committee pigeonhole at the 1958 session.

Mr. and Mrs. Sol Blackman of the Bronx and Lake Mahopac, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Blackman, to Richard L. Barovick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Barovick of the Bronx.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29 (AP)-- Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Ltd., said today the company had decided to postpone certain phases of its expansion program.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 29--The executive secretary of the State School Boards Association tonight characterized as "inaccurate and misleading" published reports that the group had endorsed yesterday a Democratic proposal aimed at reducing the high cost of borrowing for school construction.
A Hungarian refugee who said he could convert sugar directly into raw alcohol was arraigned yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of possessing an unregistered still.
IN "Pale Horse, Pale Rider," a stage adaptation of Kath erine Anne Porter's short story, the young players are faced with what appears to be most challenging, complex work of their careers.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 29 --An extensive file of source material in Russian history, sixteen packing cases of records gathered by the Czarist secret police, was opened today at the Hoover Institution. The papers concern the men and events that produced the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution.
Semi-conductors--tiny basic components of electronics-- have replaced vacuum tubes many times larger. It is a part of the snowballing trend to miniaturization.
Mrs. Nattlie Oliver, 45 years old, of 3 Kenilworth Road, Morristown, N.J., was killed when she plunged yesterday from her seventh floor room at the Sulgrave Hotel.
A United States-flag airline which was born thirty years ago this week on a 90-mile route from Key West to Havana today circles the world on routine operations.

The French political crisis has now lasted about a month and is still unsolved. The essence of the crisis is that it would not have ended if, for instance, the Socialist Guy Mollet had succeeded in winning a parliamentary majority on Monday, or if Antoine Pinay, the Right-Wing Independent, had succeeded earlier when he tried.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 29--The United States and other Western powers hope to bring the debate on the Syrian-Turkish dispute to a halt tomorrow without the adoption of a General Assembly resolution.
LONDON, Oct. 29--Peter Thorneycroft, Chancellor of the Exchequer, served notice on the unions in the nationalized industries today that the Government would not finance wage increases.
The Government filed suit in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday seeking $683 from a former Army lieutenant whose military jeep was stolen from him in the Philippine Islands in 1946.
With the sailing of the liner Flandre for France tomorrow, the French Line will have only one passenger ship--the Liberte --in North Atlantic service for the next five months.
Private industry will completely take over atomic power and other peaceful uses in the United States within a decade, Lewis L. Strauss predicted last night.

Subscribers to the sixty-ninth National Horse Show opening in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday come from nearly all parts of the United States, with a sprinkling of really ardent devotees from England and Canada.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage on Oct. 21 of Mrs. Betty Murphy Mase, daughter of Fred P. Murphy of Bronxville and Stamford, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Murphy, to John Richard Assheton, son of Mrs. Richard T. Assheton of London and the late Mr. Assheton.

Bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will visit the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company today. Both are at 195 Broadway. They also will be at the New York Telephone Company, 208 East Ninety-seventh Street.

Union members responsible for the distribution of milk to 12,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area stayed on the job last night, despite the passing of a 4 P.M. strike deadline.

Although the Princeton-Brown football game Saturday is not regarded as the big one in the Ivy League, the statistical leadership in three departments will be at stake.
MONTREAL, Oct. 29-Senator Sarto Fournier, elected mayor of Montreal yesterday, defeated Jean Drapeau by a margin of about 4,000 votes.

Robert J. Donovan, who has been serving as White House correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, has been named chief of that newspaper's Washington bureau. He succeeds Don Whitehead, who after an illness of several months has asked to be relieved.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29-- David Sarnoff called today for the free world to mount a "cold war" offensive against the Soviet Union to avert "the holocaust of hydrogen war."

Kerr-McGee Oil Industries, Inc., has contracted to purchase from the Gulf Oil Corporation a 1,100-mile crude oil gathering system in Oklahoma. The price was not announced. The transaction is scheduled to become effective Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)-- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today there was nothing evil about accepting gifts, but the problem for offi cials was difficult and delicate.

Traffic deaths in the city decreased to seven last week compared with seventeen in the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 29--Demand was selective on the stock market today. Leading industrials remained dull while interest was focused on South African gold mining and Rhodesian copper stocks. Most industrial equities lost a few pence.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company raised $250,000,000 yesterday by the sale of debentures in the public bond market. This marked the second time this year that the telephone company had raised debt capital in this manner, and the third such requisition since July, 1956.

Litigation arising out of the Andrea Doria-Stockholm disaster more than a year ago moved a step closer to settlement yesterday.
BOSTON, Oct. 29--A resolution urging the United States to stop sending arms to Arab states was adopted today by the Pioneer Women of America.

MANORHAVEN, L. I., Oct. 29--Property originally used by Pan American Airways as a base for its Clipper service in the early Nineteen Thirties was sold at public auction here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 --A new concept in studio management-labor relations was advanced today by Lester Cowan, who will operate the proposed Commonwealth Studio in Puerto Rico under a contract with the island government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) --A Mississippi Negro has protested to the Federal Communications Commission against a television station's refusal to grant him equal time to answer white politicians on racial issues.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)--A runaway engine started a fire aboard a Scandinavian DC-7 airliner at sea tonight but the crew kept the fire in check and the four-engine craft landed safely with forty-five passengers at Logan International Airport here.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP)-- Jean Croft, a 25-year-old clerk, received a big wedding present today. She learned she had won, 51,085 pounds ($143,038) on a football pool ticket.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 29 --Post-election riots, which broke out in six places in Turkey today, left a toll of three dead and at least nine critically wounded.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 29-- Senator Harry F. Byrd's field leadership of a massive attack on the Eisenhower Administration civil rights program will wind up Thursday.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP)--Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet chief of state, has sent a message to President Celal Bayar of Turkey congratulating the Turkish people on the anniversary of the proclamation of their republic, the Moscow radio said today.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 29-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer predicted today that a Western heads-of-government meeting in Paris would produce a needed demonstration of steadfastness against mounting Soviet threats.

The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Monday was steady at 84.4, the seven year low established on Friday. The last time the index was at 84.4 was on April 28, 1950. The figure for Oct. 30, 1956, was 90.6.

NAPLES, Italy, Oct. 29 (Reuters)--Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said today that North Atlantic pact forces would not move east of Cyprus during the combined three-day exercise in the Ionian and Aegean seas beginning Thursday.

A defendant who is acting as his own counsel made an unusual request of prospective jurors yesterday in General Sessions Court. He asked them if they could forget that he was sane.

Toshiya Eto played a rather strange program of violin music last night in Carnegie Hall. Once past Beethoven's "Kreutzer" Sonata, there was plenty of virtuoso material but precious little musical nourishment.

Once again the inherent absurdity of the popular election of judges is high-lighted by the number of candidates the voters of New York City must pass judgment on if they are to cast intelligent votes on Nov. 5.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30-- President Eisenhower looked well today, but sounded a little sad. The pace of the armaments race and rising costs was playing hob with his budgetary ceilings, and he obviously did not like it.

Cocoa futures rose to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices rose 53 to 77 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 944 lots The volume was the second largest since World War II and compared with 1,145 lots (30,000 pounds to a lot) on Nov. 26. 1956.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30--Defense spending in the current fiscal year probably will exceed the $38,000,000,000 ceiling by "something more" than $400,000,000, President Eisenhower said today.

Directors of Loew's, Inc., including some of the board members elected at the special stockholders' meeting two weeks ago, voted yesterday to omit the dividends normally paid in the first two quarters of the company's fiscal year, which ends Aug. 31. Stockholders in the nation's largest motion picture company had been receiving 25 cents quarterly. The latest such payment was in June.

TOMORROW, 10 P.M.: "Pup, Cub and Kitten," a photographic exhibition, opens today at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street. It shows family life of common American wild animals such as woodchucks, foxes and mice.

The second floor and part of the ground floor of the building rising at 110 William Street in the downtown insurance district have been leased by the Insurance Company of North America Companies of Philadelphia. Newly designed V-8 engines that will operate smoothly with regular grade gasoline were announced yesterday by Ford. They will comprise the bulk of the new power plants in the company's 1958 cars, which will go on sale next Thursday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 3-- Lester. B. Pearson, winner of the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize, urged the West today to seize every opportunity to negotiate toward peaceful coexistence with the Soviet Union.
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 4 (Reuters)--British scientists and newspapers described the new Soviet satellite as "fantastic" and "unbelievable."
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 3--Union electricians from Brooklyn and the Bronx are getting their mental batteries charged on a 314-acre estate that was once a millionaire's summer playground.
The National Broadcasting Company hopes to present Mary Martin in another revival of "Peter Pan" on March 31. The two-hour color production would be televised in the early evening.

OTTAWA, Nov. 3--Canada has embarked on a wheat giveaway program of her own. The Canadian Government has complained that the United States program for the disposal of surplus farm products is in violation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and is disrupting the country's normal market.
The New York Times Youth Forum turned yesterday from matters of world import to a theme less weighty but more immediate to young people: "What about going steady?"

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 3-- State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes paid a final pre-election visit to this city today. As he toured various sections, political observers said that how the electorate here would vote Tuesday was still a question.

Sterling Drug, Inc., had record sales and earnings for the first ninth months and for the third quarter of this year, James Hill Jr., chairman, reported over the week-end. The quarter's figures were a record for any quarter.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 3 (AP)-- The airlift bringing six foreign horses to Laurel for the sixth Washington, D.C., International on Nov. 11 started today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3-- Merger of three major Southern California banks to form the fifth largest banking institution in the United States and the second largest in California has received final approval from banking authorities. It will open tomorrow under the name of the Security-First National Bank.
CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 2-- Alberta's post-war oil boom, while far from a bust as yet, has certainly become deflated and the outlook for at least the next two years is for little improvement.

NEW HAVEN, No. 3 (AP)-- Two of the nation's oldest seedgrowing concerns took the first step toward a merger yesterday when directors of the Associated Seed Growers, Inc., of New Haven, and of F.H. Woodruff Sons, Inc., of Milford, Conn., signed an agreement.

GENEVA, Nov. 3--Sixty European refugees from Communist China arrived here today by air from Hong Kong. They were "hard-core cases," in the parlance of the welfare organizations that received them: sick, aged, many unable to work or walk.
The wags of the world were busy yesterday spinning shaggy dog tales and quipping about the launching of the second satellite. These were some of the results:

The Cuban Medical Association has charged that two of its member physicians and another innocent person were murdered for having ministered to insurgent wounded in fighting the regime of President Fulgencio Batista.
LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 3 --More than 1,000,000 Portuguese voters gave the thirtyone-year-old dictatorship of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar a massive demonstration of support today.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 3 (UP)--The Air Force Association charged today that missiles launched in Florida were aimed at a "target of 10,000 square miles of Atlantic Ocean."
TUNIS, Tunisia, Nov. 2--The revolutionary Algerian nationalist movement appeared this week to have begun a new phase in its three-year-old development.

The Bethlehem Day Nursery, the only day-care center on the East Side between Twentieth and Forty-second Streets, will benefit from the Nov. 13 performance of the musical comedy, "Copper and Brass," at the Martin Beck Theatre.

ROME, Nov. 3--Giuseppe di Vittorio, Italian Communist labor leader and president of the Communist-line World Federation of Trade Unions, died at Lecco tonight. His age was 65. A heart attack was reported to have been the cause of death.
The Democratic high command employed caution yesterday in predicting the plurality it expected to roll up in winning the first city election under permanent personal registration.
Any satellite, whether it be the moon or an artificial one, is held in an orbit above the earth by a balance of forces between gravity and the satellite's velocity.
A radio-controlled warning light system to promote safe passage of fire apparatus will be tested here Friday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif.,Nov.3-- James Stewart will star in "The F. B. I. Story," which Mervyn Le Roy will direct and produce for Warner Brothers.

WARSAW, Nov. 3--The Polish Government has accepted the recommendations of the economic council headed by Dr. Oskar Lange for what are described as "vital" changes in planning and management in the national economy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3-- William P. Rogers, who is to succeed Herbert Brownell Jr. as Attorney General, drives a salmon-colored Cadillac. As he parked it the other day at the Department of Justice, an attendant observed to Mr. Rogers's secretary:
A wounded burglary suspect was captured early yesterday in his attic room in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn after assertedly having eluded the police twice during the night.
A total of 12,732 New Yorkers had active cases of tuberculosis as of Dec. 31, 1956, according to a comprehensive review published today by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.
Domestic cotton prices last week moved irregularly, but losses during the period outweighed gains.
Radio signals from the second Soviet satellite were picked up yesterday at widely scattered points around the globe.

Angier Biddle Duke proposed yesterday that a conference of Western nations be called to solve the refugee problem in Europe. Mr. Duke is head of the International Rescue Committee.
Dr. Farid Zeineddine, Syrian representative to the United Nations, declared yesterday that "war may still come at any time" on the Syrian-Turkish frontier.

Tere Amoros, a young Spanish dancer who began her career in South America, made her local debut last night in Carnegie Hall. She is a lovely looking girl, with charming stage manners, a fresh and elegant wardrobe, and exquisite grooming.
WHEN Charlie Caldwell was sounded out on shifting his coaching talents from Princeton to Southern California, he shook his head in his quiet, positive fashion.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 3 (UP)--Arnold Palmer, fighting off challenges from first Al Balding, then Bob Rosburg, Mike Souchak and Billy Casper, won the $20,000 San Diego open golf tournament today with a seventeen-under-par 271 for 72 holes.

The second artificial earth satellite was launched in the Soviet Union on 3rd November. According to available information it represents the last stage of the carrier rocket housing containers with scientific instruments and radio transmitters.

THERE is something pleasing in the fact that the two Danish authors whose works are most familiar to literate Americans are both writers of fairy stories. Hans Christian Andersen's immortal stories for children have delighted adults for generations. But Isak Dinesen's subtle and sophisticated stories would never do for children.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (UP)--The New York Rangers won their third straight National Hockey League game tonight. A thirdperiod goal by Harry Howell broke a deadlock for a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.
A Bronx couple and their nephew were arraigned in Bronx Magistrates' Court yesterday and held without bail for hearing Nov. 12 in the stabbing and beating of an off-duty policeman early Saturday.
An unmanned rocket flight to the moon. An unmanned rocket flight around the moon and back to earth.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3-- Well-organized protectionists are busily laying the ground for a new assault on the reciprocal trade program.
LONDON, Nov. 3--Stock market prices continued to drift downward again last week.

Space for a sales office has been leased by the Eagle Pencil Company, pencil manufacturer, in the building being erected by the Seagram Company at 375 Park Avenue, at Fifty-second Street. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agent, represented the owner of the building.
LONDON, Nov. 3--The dismissal of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov has left Nikita S. Khrushchev far ahead of the field as the No. 1 power in the Soviet Union, in the view of diplomatic sources here.

Since the end of World War II international economic policy in the western world has centered on two major objectives. The first was the reduction of tariffs and the removal of other trade and payments obstacles with the ultimate objective of achieving general currency convertibility. The second was the economic integration of Europe.
MONTREAL, Nov. 3--A softspoken executive with a trace of a Virginia accent is the anchor man here for a hotel enterprise that is changing the economic face of midtown Montreal.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3--Steel orders last month were a disappointment to the steel industry. Hopes now rest on a substantial change this month. But if the last week was any indication of what is to come, it may be difficult to keep the steel ingot rate at its present level.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3-- Members of Congress increased their clamor today for an allout investigation of the United States satellite and missile programs.

The seventy-four-member Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, meeting in plenary conference in Rome for the next three weeks, hopes for a budget of $8,600,000 this year and $8,800,000 next year. This would cost the United States, which has been paying a little under one-third of F. A. O.'s expenses, pretty close to two cents per capita, man, woman and child.

As the world's first space traveler flew repeatedly across the United States yesterday, American radio observations indicated that it was crossing the United States on courses similar to those of the first Soviet satellite.

Mayor Wagner disclosed last night that a full investigation was under way into charges that city building inspectors had conspired with some realty interests to produce quick profits through condemnation proceedings.

The Commonwealth Fund said in its thirty-ninth annual report yesterday that fifty-four grants totaling $3,808,912 were made during the year. Ninety per cent of them were in the general area of health.

CEBU, the Philippines, Nov. 3--In this bustling commercial metropolis there are two great families, the Cuencos and the Osmenas, that have been political rivals as long as any living Filipino can remember.

Breaking the contest open with a sizzling fourth-quarter attack, the New York Knickerbockers whipped the Philadelphia Warriors, 123 to 105, in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.
A second weekly slump by the steamship charter market has completely dissipated gains achieved in a feeble mid-October recovery attempt.

CARACAS, Nov. 3 (AP)--Peter Collins of England and Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., sent their Ferrari 4100 roaring over the 1,002.93 kilometers (about 600 miles) in 6 hours 31 minutes 55 seconds today for victory in the Grand Prix of Venezuela.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, Nov. 3-- It is both somber and terrifying to view the wreckage of great civilizations. Here in the Cambodian jungles, largely obscured by foliage, lie sixty square miles of ruins, the pompous shards of Angkor. Angkor was the seat of that boastful Khmer Empire, which in its day claimed to be a super-power.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 3-- Arab oil men meeting in Baghdad are considering a plan for a joint stock company to finance future Middle Eastern pipelines with the Arab governments as the only stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3-- The United States, despite the new ventures into space, does not plan to launch its first earth satellite until next month at the earliest. Its first launching will be only of a "miniature" satellite, with launching of its first "scientific" satellite not to come, possibly, before March.

BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 3 (AP) --Dr. Alan Shapley, vice chairman of the United States International Geophysical Year Committee, said today that the second Soviet satellite could "contribute to knowledge for all mankind."
Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Left wing of the British Labor party, said yesterday he was not alarmed ay the Russians' second earth satellite and saw "no military significance" in the first one.
ALL the boards an actress faces during her career are not for treading--some are for ironing.

THE big chance seldom comes to the man who covers for the understudy. But Asian flu tends to be an indisposition of wholesale character, and because it put two New York City Opera basses out of commission on Saturday night, it gave the chance of a lifetime to Herbert Beattie, a young singer from Buffalo, who is now in his first season with the company.
LEVELLAND, Tex., Nov. 3 (UP)--A glowing egg-shaped object reportedly streaked over west Texas and New Mexico last night. One man said he saw it sitting on a highway.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 3 (UP)--A four-engine West German charter aircraft en route to New York struck a building and crashed in flames in a Duesseldorf garden today, killing seven persons. Six others were injured.

TO the novice the problem of giving a party in a small city apartment with limited kitchen facilities often seems overwhelming. It need not be, according to Nata Lee, a caterer who has had twenty-six years' experience in planning parties here.

A layman and a clergyman called yesterday on all Christians to re-establish their faith by deeds rather than by lip service if the Christian world were not to follow the fate of the Roman Empire.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3--The Soviet Union reported today that its second earth satellite was in orbit and that the dog in it was still in good health.

NELSON ROCKEFELLER came close to breaking up New York City's largest Indian encampment last September, but probably never knew it. If the Brooklyn Baseball Club had taken up his offer of twelve acres for a Dodger stadium at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, a fair number of the 800 Mohawks who live in the area would have been dispossessed.

With the removal of the last rock barrier holding back the waters of Lake Huleh, Israel's great reclamation project in northern Galilee is nearing completion. It involves the drainage into the River Jordan of some 15,000 acres of lake and swampland, and their conversion into a richly productive agricultural area.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) --The Rocky Mountain and Pacific Coast states led the nation in population growth between 1950 and July, 1956, the Census Bureau reported today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 3-- A taxi blockade that led to suspension of flighty into Nassau's new airport ended today after day-long negotiations. Commercial planes were expected to resume scheduled flights from New York and Miami.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 (UP) --George Blanda accounted for three field goals today to give the Chicago Bears a 16-10 National Football League victory over the Los Angeles Rams before a crowd of 80,456 which included former President Harry S. Truman.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals led many groups over the world yesterday in protesting the use of a dog in the new Soviet earth satellite.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3--The real estate market can look forward to another twelve months of "good business" in which prices and the trading volume will remain stable, the president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards said today.
PARIS, Nov. 3--The French Socialist party took action today that offered the first solid hope for termination early this week of France's twentyfourth and second longest postwar government crisis.

WILLIAM WARFIELD'S recital at Town Hall last night was a testimonial to his curiosity, range and probity as an artist. There was not an unworthy thing on the program, and there was scarcely a work he did not illuminate with some fresh insight. Performances of this order are rare at any time, especially among singers.

VIENNA, Nov. 3 (AP)--President Istvan Dobi of Hungary announced today abolition of the summary courts through which thousands of anti-Communists involved in last fall's revolt have been sentenced to prison or death.

Passage by the City Council of an amended anti-bias housing bill was predicted yesterday by Charles Abrams, chairman of the New York State Commission Against Dis crimination. Declaring that the measure had been carelessly drawn when introduced about five months ago, Mr. Abrams foresaw its prompt passage if penal provisions were de-emphasized and more stress were placed on conciliatory procedures.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 3-- Opposition to Mayor Thomas F.J. Quigley, a Democrat seeking his fourth term, flared anew here today at a special meeting of the Board of Education.

Joseph Meyers of 50 Sutton Place South, president and founder of Avon Publications, Inc., and allied publishing companies, died Saturday in Los Angeles after a short illness. He had been on a business trip. His age was 59.
"THE Seven Lively Arts" had its long-awaited premiere yesterday afternoon. John Houseman's initial television flirtation with the muses was more tantalizing in title than in performance.

Plans are being worked out to transfer "Mary Stuart" to a Broadway theatre after it ends its successful run at the Phoenix on Nov. 24. T. Edward Hambleton, co-producer at the Second Avenue playhouse, said yesterday that the likelihood of such a move was "extremely good."
THE most famous dog in the world today is a laika that is traveling farther from the earth than any living creature has done before.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Modlin of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Kay Modlin, to Lawrence Ely Grolnick. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Grolnick of Brooklyn and Huntington, L.I.

SEVENTH Avenue is having its little joke again. About sex. In Sam Locke's "Fair Game," which opened at the Longacre Saturday night a divorcee is hired as a dress model and since she is a divorcee, beautiful and a perfect size 10, every wolf in the trade is on her trail.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (UP)-- Earl Morrall threw two touchdown passes to Ray Mathews today as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Baltimore Colts, 19--13.

In the home of her parents this afternoon Miss Joy Edna Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Heller of 26 East Sixty-third Street, was married to George W. Rosenthal. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rosenthal of San Francisco.

LONDON, Nov. 3--Sir Winston Churchill's leadership of Britain in World War II is the subject of colorful anecdotes in a book of war reminiscences by Maj. Gen. Sir John Kennedy, which is to be published tomorrow.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 3--The Dutch Government is taking strong measures in an effort to stabilize and, wherever possible, lower price levels. The Rev. Dr. Paul S. James preached his first sermon as pastor of the new Southern Baptist Chapel here yesterday morning. BERLIN, Nov. 3--The struggle between the Evangelical Church and the Communist regime of East Germany is becoming more plainly a fight for the minds of youth. This was apparent today from a sermon and an editorial.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 4-- Favored Adam Frisco, driven by George Phalen, scored a threequarter-length victory over Hugh Worthy in the first mileand-a-sixteenth race of the season, the Cambridge pace, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Broadway finally will get the long-awaited "La Plume de Ma Tante" in March. The Jack Hylton production of the intimate revue, which achieved a London run of almost twenty months, will be imported by David Merrick and Joseph Kipness.

The Fund for the Republic will make an inquiry into the role of religion in American life. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the nonprofit organization established by the Ford Foundation, announced the study yesterday.

Debutantes of several nations will be presented to society here at the third International Debutante Ball, which will be held in the ballroom of the Ambassador on Dec. 30. The Nephrosis Foundation of New York will benefit from the event, which is sponsored by Lufthansa Airlines.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (AP)-- The Cleveland Indians today hired Frank (Trader) Lane as general manager. He will have a free hand in getting the Tribe back in the first division.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 --A significant partnership in the changing pattern of the motion picture business has been formed between Warner Brothers Pictures and National Theatres, Inc., the country's secondlargest movie theatre chain.

Steel production last month was well below the level of October last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Output for the first ten months this year, however, was at a record high.

The Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy has taken blocks of seats for four major Broadway productions. Proceeds of the theatre parties will help the organization's student ticket fund as well as its goal to realize a permanent repertory theatre in New York.

Robert J. Lewis was elected president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms at the annual meeting of the board of governors yesterday. Mr. Lewis, a partner in Estabrook Co. here, succeeds E. Jansen Hunt, a partner in White, Weld Co., also of New York.
New York City borrowed $36,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, street paving and the payment of judgments and claims.

Baizerman was born in 1889 and studied at the Imperial Art School in Odessa. He left Russia in 1909, went first to England and finally to the United States, where he began his caieer as an academic sculptor.

IN its first visit of the season to Carnegie Hall last night the Boston Symphony Orchestra brought generous gifts. WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Robert C. Hill, new United States Ambassador to Mexico City, is getting a kick out of his job, and Mexico is getting a kick out of him.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- United States officials have worked out a fairly comprehensive program of military proposals for the North Atlantic Council meeting next month.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17-- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower planned to consult with Adlai E. Stevenson before next month's Atlantic Pact meeting in Paris.
EUGENE LIST yesterday afternoon brought to New York the program that he and the Knickerbocker Players are performing on a fiftydate concert tour of the United States.

Guatemala appears set for an extensive search for oil if order is maintained. The Bureau of Mines of the Guate malan Ministry of Economy has announced that thirty-nine exploratory permits covering 3,785,324 hectares, or 9,353,527 acres, have been granted under the 1955 petroleum law.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Nov.17--Five New Jersey deer hunters were fined more than $200 each today for hunting in Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park.
The year's largest turnout of advertising people is expected tomorrow and Wednesday at the annual Eastern conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Personal income declined in October for the second straight month. It was the first twomonth decline since late 1953 and early 1954, when income fell for several months in the middle of a mild business recession.

Maurice Courland, senior partner in the firm of Maurice Courland Son, architects and engineers, 2112 Broadway, died Saturday night in Jewish Memorial Hospital of a heart attack. His home was 285 Central Park West. He was 65 years old.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has sold 595 Third Avenue, a one-story taxpayer building at the southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street. The building is 65 by 78 feet and is occupied under lease as an A. P. supermarket. It was bought by an investing client of the Cross Brown Company, broker in the transaction.
LONDON, Nov. 17--George F. Kennan declared tonight that serious problems involving the Soviet Union could not be solved by top-level meetings with the Russians.
Nikita S. Khrushchev was obviously bragging when he gave an interview to The United Press last week. He gloated over Soviet superiority in rockets and missiles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) --George Morris Fay, former United States Attorney, who was the District of Columbia's top prosecutor from 1946 to 1951, died of cancer today at Georgetovm University Hospital, where he underwent an operation yesterday. He was 48 years old.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17--The steel business has become high ly competitive, with delivery the big factor in "getting the order." The volume of new business is about unchanged from a month ago, but comparisons are difficult because of "last-minute" orders.

Organized teachers charged yesterday that a misleading view here "equates difficult children with 'dark complexion.'" They bitterly denied any concerted effort to avoid serving in schools with many Negro and Puerto Rican pupils.
SINCE Burt Marnik resents the treatment of the Ne groes in the South, he has done something about it. He has written three one-act plays under the group title of "The Twisting Road."
Cardinal Spellman appealed in a pastoral letter yesterday for clothing and funds for "the stricken and forsaken of the world regardless of race, color or creed."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- The National Academy of Sciences announced here today that Dr. Warren Weaver, vice president for natural and medical sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, would receive the academy's annual Public Welfare Medal.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov.17-- Little Rock has completed its seventh week of school integration under the protection of the United States Army, but no immediate solution to the Federalstate deadlock appears to be in sight.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved up last week. At the close of trading on Friday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 39 to 105 points for the week. Sharpest improvement was recorded by the nearer deliveries.
LONDON, Nov. 17----The decision of the United States Federal Reserve Board to permit a reduction in the discount rate had a favorable effect on British stock markets last week.
The annual financial report of the Board of Higher Education gives a comprehensive picture, to taxpayers and others, of the uniquely large contribution that New York City makes to municipal colleges.
PARIS, Nov. 17 (AP)----Two American fur breeders said today they had offered $7 million for a controlling interest in the Dior fashion house.
THE young modern homemaker may boast the latest scientific equipment in her kitchen yet, at the same time, she is obviously entranced by antique food molds.
Many socially prominent persons are working for the success of the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball to be held on Dec. 20 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
After nearly five years of effort, a United Nations housing development at Ossining and Briarcliff Manor is under way.
Detroit is planning to sell bond issues totalling $4,606,000 on Nov. 26. Dated last Friday, the securities will come due serially on Nov. 15 from 1958 to 1982.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- When George Frost Kennan said in a speech tonight that a top-level conference could not resolve the West's differences with the Soviet Union, he expressed a sentiment that would find a ready "Hear! Hear!" from Secretary of State Dulles.
JASPER, Ala., Nov. 17 (UP) --Tornadoes struck Alabama and Mississippi today, killing at least five persons and injuring at least six in rural communities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) --Lou Groza's 23-yard field goal in the last thirteen seconds enabled the Cleveland Browns to salvage a 30-30 tie with the Washington Redskins today before 27,722 fans.

HARRISON, N, Y., Nov. 17---- A 20-year-old driver was booked on two charges today stemming from an accident in which two girls were killed yesterday and eleven other passengers of a total of fifteen riding in the car were injured.
The steamship charter market remained static throughout most of last week. The approach of winter has had none of its normal salutary effect upon the field.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 17 ----Without winning any of the afternoon's seven races, Jack Sutphen today sailed his Rum Dum to a second consecutive frostbite dinghy regatta victory at Larchmont Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Senate rackets investigators have subpoenaed files of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners. They refused to say today what they were looking for.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17--Frank Capra, director-producer, has taken over Columbia's problem picture, "Joseph and His Brethren." The studio has an investment reportedly approaching $1,000,000 in the Biblical story.

Even on a bad day the Giants had too much for the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday at Yankee Stadium. Winning with their weakest offense of the season, the New Yorkers turned back Hughie Devore's tail-end team, 13----0, and gained a half game on the pace-setting Cleveland Browns, who tied the Redskins at Washington.
"Winston Churchill and the Second Front," an analysis by Trumbull Higgins, will be published by Oxford University Press Dec. 5.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 17 (AP) ----The Los Angeles Rams, led by Norm Van Brocklin and Jon Arnett, staged a 28-point rally in the second half to beat the Green Bay Packers, 31----27, in, a National Football League game today.

NEWARK, Nov. 17--A pert, young wire-haired foxterrier, Ch. Mitre Miss Adorable, completed what for her was a perfect dog show week-end today. She added best in show at the Newark Kennel Club event to the one she had taken yesterday in Yonkers.
A state survey indicated yesterday that thousands of jobless workers were more interested in finding work than in rushing in claims for unemployment insurance.
CAIRO, Nov. 17--President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have called an abrupt halt to Egypt's violent propaganda campaign against King Hussein and the pro-Western Government of Jordan.
Race-hate groups have forced units of the National Urban League out of community chests in six Southern cities and are pressing for its exclusion in seventeen others.
The Russian satellites were discussed in sermons yesterday by some of the city's most prominent preachers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Foreign Minister Christian Pineau of France will ask the United States Tuesday for help in attaining a general FrenchTunisian agreement.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov, 17 --A corps of Civil War quarterbacks met on the fields of Gettysburg today to learn over all the old lessons, and to look for new ones.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that the United States must rebuild mutual confidence with its allies in the Atlantic Pact. He said it also must be prepared to curb with military force Communist-started "brush fires" anywhere in the world.

A panel of high school students and a conservation expert urged yesterday an educational campaign to make Americans more conservation-minded. The panel and the expert agreed that the nation was wasting its natural resources.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17-- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, announced today his opposition to transfer of the St. Lawrence Seaway project from the Army to the Department of Commerce.
DEAR SANTA: Women are mysterious, fickle and expensive. Especially at Christmas time.
ROME, Nov. 17--The Italian armed forces, about 400,000 strong, are about to be equipped with missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads.
Eight Protestant leaders broke ground symbolically yesterday for the Interchurch Center near Columbia University.

Everyone is familiar with the fact that from time to time reason, in the stock market, gives way to the herd instinct and that the result in such cases is a stampede----a stampede to get into the market or to get out of it.

BOLZANO, Italy, Nov. 17-- About 20,000 members of the South Tyrol People's party, which represents the Germanspeaking residents in the Province of Bolzano, demonstrated decorously this morning, airing their grievances against the Italian Government.

PLATTSBURGH AIR FORCE BASE, N.Y., Nov. 17 (UP)--Six United States B-52 jet bombers landed here today after making a 10,425-mile non-stop round-trip flight between the United States and Argentina in 21 hours and 42 minutes.

THE General Motors "Fiftieth Anniversary Show" seen last night on Channel 4, was a superb musical production, rewardingly experimental in approach, delightfully humorous and touchingly poignant. It was artistic television of a high order.
The Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, proposed yesterday the establishment of a university research center on mass communications.

Labor and the Conservative Government in Britain are lining up for a monumental controversy over wages in relation to prices. This will be especially interesting to us in this country because the issue is also such a hot one here.
Sputnik has awakened us. I am glad it has, But simply a greater effort in scientific research and missile development is not a sufficient response to the challenge which is now apparent.
TOKYO, Nov. 17--Premier Nobusuke Kishi will leave tomorrow on a three-week tour touching six Sotuheast Asian countries and Singapore, Australia and New Zealand.

The Chilean Order of Merit has been awarded to Jakob Isbrandtsen, president of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., for assisting in the development of the South American nation's mining industry, it was reported at the week-end.

Ken Kelley, a tricky runner who was a difficult tackling target for the Giants yesterday, provided the best running for the Philadelphia Eagles, the team that was able to move consistently, but never far enough. The Eagles rushed for 215 yards. They did not score.

SOUTH BYFIELD, Mass., Nov. 17----Jim Barriskill, a teacher of Latin and Spanish at Governor Dummer Academy is ----by his own admission--no devotee of sports. He has a small interest in soccer but confesses to only a passing knowledge of its finer points.
Pleas by anti-Hoffa elements to keep the International Brotherhood of Teamsters inside the merged labor federation got a cold welcome yesterday from federation leaders.
CHICAGO, Nov, 17 (AP)----Milt Davis' pass interceptions, including a 47-yard scoring return, led the Baltimore Colts to a 29----14 victory over the Chicago Bears before 47,168 at Wrigley Field today.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y. Nov. 17--The Conservative branch of American Judaism added a record 130 congregations to its roster in the last two years. The largest previous gain was 101, made in the biennium 1953-55.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17-- Adolfo Lopez Mateos, nominated yesterday as the Institutional Revolutionary party's Presidential candidate, launched his campaign today.

For the next several weeks letters and packages will be gaily decorated with those happy harbingers of the Yuletide--Christmas seals. The fifty-first annual seal sale is under way and will last through Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) --The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision against the German manufacturer Fritz von Opel in his effort to recapture American assets seized as enemy property during World War II.
LAS CRUCES, N.M., Nov. 18 (AP)--Cora Witherspoon, who had been an actress for half a century, died of a heart ailment yesterday at her home here. She was 67 years old.
Mrs. Hazel Sharper, whose arrest Sept. 26 brought about a Police Department investigation, was cleared in Lower Manhattan Court yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct.

Research on an area of the human brain that records experiences and preserves them in detail was described last night by one of the world's leading authorities on brain function. He is Dr. Wilder Penfield, director of the Montreal Neurological Institute.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 18 --The five-man military junta that governs Colombia announced today the armed forces and intelligence service had thwarted a plot to overthrow the Government early this morning.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 18, (AP)--A joint Syrian-Egyptian parliamentary session called today on the two governments to open negotiations immediately for federal union of Syria and Egypt.
ADVENTURES IN NUMBERS AND SPACE," a filmed television program designed to make mathematics attractive to young people, had its debut last night on Channel 5.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 18-- The 41,000-mile interstate highway system will cost at least 30 per cent more than the original $27,500,000,000 estimate, the American Automobile Association was told today.

The police started the city's new educational campaign against jaywalking at six busy intersections yesterday, and got careful and cheerful cooperation. Elsewhere, pedestrians kept crossing streets with typical disregard for rules and traffic perils.

La Hermosa (The Beautiful), a $500,000 church and community center for Puerto Ricans, is to replace an old motion picture theatre at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street in the heart of a crowded Puerto Rican district of the city.
The formation of the HeilQuaker Corporation with assets of $10,000,000 to produce home heating and air conditioning was announced yesterday by Joseph F. Heil, chairman, and C.W. Milligan, president.

George Meany has sent a sharp letter tp top officials of the International Jewelry Workers Union demanding an end to the exploitation of Puerto Rican workers by member locals and greater adherence by the union to labor's code of ethics.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18--Los Angeles radio listeners will be hearing something new --editorials expressing station management's point of view-- in the near future.
A high-powered, long-range radar installation for research in ballistic missile defense has been completed in Massachusetts.
The Coca-Cola Company had a consolidated net profit of $24,766,970 in the first nine months this year. This was 2.2 per cent more than the $24,242,976 cleared in the 1956 period.
If a child is a slow reader, he may be kept back when his classmates in the city schools graduate this June.
Governor Harriman met with top state law enforcement officials yesterday to plan for a crackdown on racketeers and hoodlums in the private garbage industry in the metropolitan area.

Reflecting the results of last Saturday, when Oklahoma's forty-seven-game winning streak came to an end and the Texas Aggies and Iowa also were beaten, Michigan State was returned to the top of the college football ratings yesterday.

The structure of the labor force in American industry is changing, and automation is a major reason for it, the National Industrial Conference board reported yesterday after questioning 130 companies.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 18--The South Pole was one of the most healthful places in the world until spring brought in visitors.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18--The United States formally presented today its proposal for a new $100,000,000 fund to aid under-developed countries.
The 27-year-old Empress of Scotland will sail from Montreal today to be sold in Britain. Shipping experts said the Canadian Pacific ship, might become a cruise vessel operating in southern waters.
Dr. Seth Minot Milliken, a retired surgeon and civic leader, died yesterday in his home at 951 Madison Avenue. His age was 82. He retired in 1952.
The Beneficial Management Corporation has terminated an eleven-year relationship with Reach, McClinton Co., Inc. Billings are estimated between $2,000,000 and $2,500,000 a year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18-- Brazil's petroleum monopoly, known as Petrobras, expects crude oil production this year to be double that of 1956.

Leaders in labor and Government attended yesterday a mass of requiem for Martin T. Lacey, prominent Teamster Union official and president of the city Central Trades and Labor Council. Mr. Lacey died Wednesday at his home in Westwood, N.J., in his seventy-fifth year.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I., Nov. 18--The blast of a whistle and the clang of a bronze bell reverberated over the hills as an old black steam engine began its trip from nowhere to nowhere on an estate here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- Navy officials indicated today that the Navy might launch a fully equipped earth satellite before its March target date-- possibly in January.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 18 --The Soviet employers' delegation was admitted today to the Asian regional conference of the International Labor Organization with "deputy" status.
MANILA, Nov. 18 (Reuters) --President Carlos P. Garcia said tonight that the Philippines' foreign policy would remain pro-American and antiCommunist.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18--The General Assembly's Political Committee approved an eleven-power resolution today urging continued efforts to effect a peaceful settlement in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- Two high Defense Department officials were silenced today as they tried to protest against statements made by an investigating subcommittee chairman. The incident arose as hearings resumed on alleged suppression of information to which the public was entitled.

SINGERS appear often enough with orchestras in oratorios, cantatas and concert versions of operas, but are rarely invited to sing art songs. Leave it to Thomas Scherman to remember an old idea and to prove that it is still viable.

Jack Rothenberg, president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, declared yesterday that the "constant pressure" by retailers to get manufacturers to reduce prices and force a higher mark-up "is not consistent with good business."
LONDON, Nov. 18--Stock market prices continued to advance today although some stocks closed slightly below their best after Wall Street's dull opening.
TO SEE "Conversation Piece" again, at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre where it was performed last evening, is to be reminded of its original purpose: Noel Coward...
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 18-- The Government of Ghana appears to have settled on a course of moderation for the immediate future in dealing with problems of internal security.

The Indonesian Government of President Sukarno is set to press again before the General Assembly this week its claim to the last Dutch foothold in the Far East-- West New Guinea, which the Indonesians call West Irian.

LONDON, Nov. 18--Indications are multiplying here and on the Continent that the United States and the Governments associated with it in the Atlantic alliance will encounter serious political problems in their efforts to remake the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., NOV. 18 --Governor Harriman assailed today the "budget wringers" in Washington. He said he suspected they might use the present emphasis on defense as an opportunity to curb advances in welfare.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18--The popular Eastern States Antiques Fair opened here today at 1 P.M. at the Westchester County Center.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18--The Soviet Union has placed high priority on its program for maintaining and improving relations with Egypt.

Although it is impossible to be precise about the degree to which we are behind the Russians, the consensus of informed opinion is that we are trailing them in our major missile programs by anywhere from a few months to as much as two or three years.
City Court Justice Roger J. Brock died yesterday in the Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn, yesterday. His age was 52. His home was at 87 Eighty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--This is the third installment of what was intended to be a two-part analysis of opposing estimates of the military posture of the United States vis-a-vis the Soviet Union.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 18-- The line-up of officials to head West Europe's key supranational institutions appears to have reached its final form.

TORONTO, Nov. 18--A Canadian steel executive charged today that the United States was forcing Canada to impose tolls on the Welland Canal section of the St. Lawrence Seaway. Thus, he said, the economy of the steel city of Hamilton and the industrialized Niagara Peninsula is threatened.

When the late Robert Falcon Scott went to the South Pole in 1912 thixty-five days behind Roald Amundsen he and his ill-fated but magnificently courageous companions left ponies and dogs behind and depended on manpower for the final dash.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- Army efforts to streamline forces for nuclear warfare--including the possible elimination of K.P.--were outlined to defense transportation leaders today.
The Communist technical challenge demands positive new action by the United States to increase the free world's economic strength, but not on an emergency basis, according to C. Douglas Dillon.

Financial circles are discussing the possibility that some of the voting common stock of A., the huge grocery chain, will be offered to the public. The main question seems to be: When? One informed source said yesterday it would take at least a year to iron out the complicated details.
PARIS, Nov. 18--The French Parliament is being asked once again to try to agree on a political reform policy for revolttorn Algeria.

A public hearing on raising the New York Blue Cross premium rate opened yesterday before Leffert Holz, State Superintendent of Insurance. Affected are nearly 7,000,000 insured members and the hospitals that serve them.
Governor Harriman charged last night that the national Administration "is not laying the facts frankly" about the space age before the American public.
LONDON, Nov. 18--Britain and France have agreed to link their electricity systems.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Nov. 18--This was the kind of day that duck and goose hunters sit around all year and wait for. They then talk about it for months to anybody who will listen, like a man who takes cold baths.
VIVE LA FRANCE! Just when it seemed there could be nothing new in coasters, the canny Gauls thought up another gambit.
MAEBASHI, Japan, Tuesday, Nov. 19--William S. Girard was found guilty today in the fatal shooting of a Japanese woman, but a sentence of three years was suspended.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y. Nov. 18--The formation of a World Council of Synagogues to stimulate Jewish religious life was unanimously approved today by the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America. The United Synagogue represents the Conservative branch of Judaism in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) --The Treasury said today it would seek to refinance nearly $10 billion of maturing securities at a more favorable interest rate than it has been able to get since last spring.

Slashing winds and tornadoes, flash floods, lightning and heavy snowstorms struck at wide areas of the midwest and the South yesterday, killing at least fourteen persons, The Associated Press reported.

John Crosby, television host on "The Seven Lively Arts," has been barred by the Columbia Broadcasting System from appearing on Mike Wallace's interview program on the American Broadcasting Company network. Mr. Crosby also is television critic for The New York Herald Tribune.
The importance of manned aircraft to the nation's military security was stressed last night by Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense.

With such stars as Chet Forte, Ted Dwyer and Bob Lehner no longer on the scene, Lou Rossini, Columbia's basketball coach, is faced with an arduous task this season. In numbers, the Lions have good potential but lack of height is a factor that is causing Rossini considerable concern.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 18--Premier David Ben-Gurion refused tonight to loosen Israel's ties with the West as a means of improving her relations with the Soviet Union.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 18 (AP)--An Air Force colonel said today that 70 per cent of the American soldiers captured in Korea became traitors to their country.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18--The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad declared today an extra divident of 50 cents on its common stock for 1957 but cut the regular dividend total for 1958 from $2 to $1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) --The State Department announced today a code of ethics barring United States diplomats from accepting from foreign dignitaries gifts that might be interpreted as bribes.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 18--A revolt in the dominant Westchester Republican organization resulted in the adoption tonight of special legislation by the Board of Supervisors to increase the pay of its members by $56,700 a year. The vote was 34 to 6.

LONDON, Nov. 18--Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd urged today that the "difference of opinion" between France, Britain and the United States over the shipment of arms to Tunisia "be kept in proper perspective."

Jack Amiel's Mr. Turf won the Setauket Handicap, the classified race that featured the program at Jamaica yesterday. It was a matter of "playing with children" for the 8-year-old Amiel color-bearer was oldest of the seven thoroughbreds that competed in the mile-and-a-sixteenth event.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) The nation's major aluminum producers said today that the industry could look forward to a bright future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- The chairman of the Senate's rackets hunting unit said tonight that it would "take some laws" to clean up corruption in labor. He explained that labor could not possibly do the job by itself.

Instead, there was a vast feeling of relief that the general letdown had not ended in defeat and the conversation pointedly avoided the game that had just been completed.
