THE nation's number one missile man is a 6 foot 2 major general who goes about his awesome task with the relaxed precision of a champion golfer sinking a one-foot putt.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., NOV. 18--A New York City detective said today "of course" the gangland convention broken up by the state police near here on Thursday was linked with the murder of Albert Anastasia, executioner of Murder, Inc.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18--About 100 seamen aboard chartered planes, reported coming here to man strike-bound Canadian National (West Indies) steamship vessels, were ordered back to Kingston, Jamaica, yesterday, it was disclosed today.
LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 17-- Bets are being taken here for the "Capital of Europe" sweepstakes.

MAEBASHI, Japan, Nov. 18 --It was a cold windy day last Jan. 30 on an upland field near this provincial city when William S. Guard, 22-year-old army specialist third class, raised his rifle and fired an expended cartridge case from a grenade launcher on its muzzle.

There are few countries in Latin America which have had a harder row to hoe in these last two years than Argentina. Gen. Juan Peron, the dictator who was ousted in September, 1955, left his nation in appalling condition.

The athlete who played the leading role in Clifton's upset football victory over Montclair is a bookish, 18-year-old fullback with steel-gray eyes, a serious nature and the belief that good things happen in twos.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 --Regal Films, which has a production-distribution agreement with Twentieth CenturyFox, plank to put ten pictures before the cameras during the next three months.
Most of the unfinished business of establishing conference champions and bowl game pairings is on the agenda for the last full program of the intercollegiate football season this week.
Stockholders of the Columbia Pictures Corporation, at their annual meeting here yesterday, ratified a new contract with A. Montague, vice president. It will be dated June 1, 1957, and run five years.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18-- Merle Rose driven by Stanley Dancer, scored a one-and-threequarter-length victory over Kirk's Queen in the Corona pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Her time for the mile and a sixteenth was 2:13 3-5.
Elevators are being used increasingly by juvenile delinquents as hiding places for stolen goods and narcotics, a police official testified here yesterday.

Matt Dubey and Harold Karr, the two young composers who provided the songs for Ethel Merman's current vehicle, "Happy Hunting," have leased the stage rights to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film "Viva Villa!"
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP)--The City of Niagara Falls was ordered today to present its objections to the proposed $600,000,000 Niagara power project although it had voted last week to drop them.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18--French Foreign Minister Christian Pineau asked United Nations officials today to discuss the coming debate on the Algerian problem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18-- Senator Henry M. Jackson warned today that Congress might have to increase taxes to finance an all-out nuclear defense program.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP)--Except in wheat, demand for grain futures increased today and prices on the Board of Trade closed steady to firm.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 18 --The Suffolk County District Attorney, in a surprise move here today, asked that the confessed knife-slayer of a Brentwood housewife and her two small children be spared a possible death penalty.

WHAT might be called esthetic gregariousness is the impelling force behind a special category of art dealers. These dealers, known in Europe as "marchands-amateurs" or "connoisseurs-marchands" are scholars and enthusiasts first, and dealers as a matter of course.

An announcement here yesterday by United Artists of its present and future production plans indicates the distributing and financing company has swung in line with the current trend in the motion picture industry toward high-budget or "blockbuster" films.
The Mayflower II bobbed gently on the murky waters of Gowanus Bay yesterday. She paused briefly and then with the aid of a tug headed into a drvdock.

The permanent financing of the Connecticut Turnpike was carried forward yesterday by the sale of $35,000,000 of serial bonds secured by pledges of the state's motor vehicle tax revenues and earnings from the project.

Crawford Kennedy, a 22-yearold Michigan State sophomore, replaced his older brother as the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America cross-country champion yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 18 --A Harvard economist suggested today that too much ridicule had been heaped on the Northern greenbacks and the Confederate paper currency that financed the Civil War.
Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, told party critics of his leadership yesterday that "I intend to stay."
Four reporters, a music and drama critic and a city editor have been awarded newspaper fellowship grants of $5,000 each for study abroad during 1958.

Miss Joan F.Lanston and Donald S. Coons are co-chairmen of a junior committee that has been formed to work for the success of a theatre party for the benefit of the George Junior Republic of Freeville, N. Y. The event will take place..
Bill Svoboda, one of the Giants' linebackers, will be able to play against the Cardinals in Chicago next Sunday, Coach Jim Lee Howell said yesterday.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 19-- A two-man Soviet delegation arrived here today to make overtures for the establishment of a trade connection with Ghana and possibly for the opening of a diplomatic mission.
The American Bar Association, which charges that lawyers frequently are misrepresented in television dramas, has initiated plans for a program to depict the profession in a "more accurate light."
PARIS, Nov. 19--The French National Assembly voted its confidence in the Government tonight.

Robert L. Joseph has added a second play by George Tabori to his production schedule for next season. It is called "The Absent Minded Murders." The producer already owns the same playwright's satirical comedy, "Brouhaha."

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 --The conference of Civil War historians ended here today with a statement that the Union had won the war on a "revolutionary" aim of equality that the United States was only now trying to fulfill.

Army's football cadets have inched ahead of Mississippi in the race for the major college rushing championship, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
LONDON, Nov. 19--The stock market was fairly buoyant today. Prices were marked lower at the outset but subsequently losses either were reduced or turned into net gains.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 19 (AP) --A revolutionary force preparing to sail for Cuba in a yacht loaded with arms, medical supplies and military uniforms was seized by United States agents today in the Florida Keys.
The trial of James R. Hoffa on charges of conspiring to use illegal wiretaps will start here Friday. Hoffa is president-elect of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 19--Dr. Luther Gulick today called on municipalities in large metropolitan areas to rise above local politics and work together to create needed regional governmental machinery.

The New York Rangers, sudden climbers to first place in the National Hockey League, will meet the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight at 7:30. The New Yorkers have lost only one game in their last nine contests and lead the Montreal Canadiens by one point.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) --Representatives of the domestic mining industry laid before the Tariff Commission today a proposed plan for imposing quotas on lead and zinc imports.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- The Army announced today that all regular troops would be withdrawn from Little Rock, Ark., Nov. 27, the day before Thanksgiving.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 --The Roman Catholic hierarchy of the United States has ordered a one-year study of "the most suitable and acceptable means" of bringing radio and television programs under the moral scrutiny of the church.

The Government moved yesterday to throw Vincent J. Squillante into prison until next February. Squillante is the reputed kingpin of a $50,000,000a-year garbage disposal business in the metropolitan area.
THIS year the big Whitney Museum annual, which opens today, takes in painting in oil and in water-color and also sculpture instead of being confined to work in a single medium.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press)--Lieut. W. A. Ringrose of Ireland tonight rode Ballynonty to a speedy victory in an individual event of the international jumping competitions at the Royal Winter Fair.

Recent Soviet gains in military rockets and earth satellites have led to a justified public demand that we catch up with and surpass the Soviet Union in these fields. But it would be disastrous if our attention were to become exclusively concentrated upon this military competition, to the neglect of the area of economic competition.
New York State savings and loan associations need branch equality with commercial banks and broader investment powers, a study released in advance of the 1958 legislative session contends.
RUDRAPUR, India, Nov. 13 --In the land of the Blacks Waters, for centuries a vastness of jungle, disease and swampy desolation, pioneers in turbans have been fighting a war for seven years.

Cocoa continued yesterday to register sharp price movements, falling the daily limit of 1 cent a pound during trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Toward the close prices recovered slightly from the lows.

TRENTON, Nov. 19--The Mercer County Grand Jury charged today that this city has been the scene of a "shocking" housing blight for the last five years. In a presentment handed up to Superior Court Judge J. Edward Knight, the panel described the slum conditions as a "malignancy that is slowly throttling" the community.

Dick Winterbauer, the talented Yale quarterback whose passes helped the Elis to a 20-13 victory over Princeton last Saturday, gained the Ivy League total-offense lead by that performance and tossed Princeton out of first place in team defense, according to statistics released yesterday.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley expressed satisfaction yesterday with the first two days of the city's educational campaign against jaywalking.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19--The Government's promise to wipe out the housing shortage in ten to twelve years confronts Communists here with numerous problems.

TRAGEDIES in sports usually are minor and rarely do they have any lasting impact, But the fates behaved cruelly to Willie Gardner and his career was perminated abruptly, almost before it began. That's the sickening part of it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- Secretary of State Dulles and Foreign Minister Christian Pineau of France agreed today to seek means by which Western arms could be delivered to Tunisia without eventually reaching the Algerian rebels.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19--The General Assembly added fourteen members to the United Nations Disarmament Commission today, bringing it to twenty-five, The Assembly hoped, by this step, to influence the Soviet Union to participate in the commission negotiations.

When Douglas Southall Freeman died in 1953, his biography of George Washington was unfinished. Five volumes had been published and he had finished the writing and revision of a large part of another volume.

News that athletic teams representing New York University are to be known henceforth as Violet Vikings probably comes as a relief to many alumni of the venerable institution of higher learning. Where colleges often select as the nicknames of their warriors on gridiron and basketball court
A few words from Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, checked a sharp decline at the tail end of yesterday's session on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Nov.19--The Federal Government is creating an emergency transport agency with power to control all intercity transportation in a war emergency.
VIENNA, Nov. 19--Antonin Novotny, First Secretary of the Communist party, received the additional post of President of Czechoslovakia today.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 19-- A Jersey City Fine Arts Council" to foster cultural endeavors and activities" was established today by the City Commission. Its first task will be to try to solve the financial problems of the Jersey City Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra.
Building construction costs throughout the nation rose 3 per cent during the twelve months through September, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, construction news and marketing specialists.
George Alpert, president and chairman of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, advocated public subsidies for the line yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19--The Soviet Union agreed today to give Egypt economic assistance. Moscow acted in answer to an urgent appeal from President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

The Organization of American States, which is our hemispheric equivalent of the United Nations, functions so smoothly that we have almost come to take it for granted. It carries on, the oldest and most effective regional organization in the world.
The New York Central Railroad asked for permission yesterday to increase its commutation fares in Westchester County by 13.12 per cent.

Everyone in New York is aware of the growing proportion of the population who are colored. The New York State Commission Against Discrimination has now buttressed that impression with figures that challenge attention--and action.
Leonard Bernstein has been named the musical director of the New York Philharmonic for the next three years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 --Samuel Goldwyn acknowledged today that there was some foundation to Hollywood reports that he has encountered opposition by certain Negro performers in casting his production of "Porgy and Bess."
The International Longshoremen' s Association revealed yesterday that it had received a new proposal of increased collaboration with Harry Bridges' West Coast dock union.

HENRY COWELL, a 60 year-old American, and Armin Schibler, a 37-year-old Swiss, were the composers who had sizable pieces introduced to New York last night by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to vacate a lower court decision that upheld the Customs Bureau's seizure of some imported nudist magazines.

The Harness Tracks of America (H. T. A.) implied yesterday they would be forced to resign from the United States Trotting Association unless that governing body amended certain bylaws and regulations that violate Federal antitrust laws.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 19--A set of "standards for synagogue practice" was adopted here today by the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America, the congregational arm of the Conservative branch of Judaism in this country.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 19--William Lambert Kleitz, president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died of head injuries here today in United Hospital. His age was 63. He had been injured last Saturday When he fell from a ladder while removing pine needles and leaves from gutters of his home on Boxwood Lane, Rye.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 (AP)--Bob Pettit tallied 38 points as the St. Louis Hawks beat the New York Knickerbockers, 118--115, tonight.

The International Business Machines Corporation took the wraps off its contender for the electronic bank of the future yesterday. At a special demonstration at its product development laboratory at Poughkeepsie, I.B.M. showed in action high-speed equipment that automatically pro cessed intermixed checks-big and little, card and paper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Eleven smaller customs headquarters offices have been eliminated and their functions merged with offices near by, the Treasury said today. This reduces the number of customs districts to thirty-four.
The New York police are centering their search for the slayers of Albert Anastasia, executioner of Murder, Inc., on the underworld figures who attended last Thursday's gangland convention upstate.
Although his team has rebounding strength and enough good shotmakers, Coach Howand Cann would be happier if his New York University basketball team packed more punch in the backcourt.

Well over a century ago the Rev. T. R. Malthus (1766-1834) expounded his famous theory that population tends to multiply faster than the means of subsistence. In highly civilized nations this was pretty much disproved. Yesterday Victor Lebow, New York marketing consultant, spoke at the Babson Institute of Business Administration in Wellesley Hills, Mass., on "A Malthusian Theory for Retailers."
The Board of Education's school construction program was called wasteful yesterday by Harold Riegelman.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 19-- Turkey has started a general withdrawal of troops from the southern section of the country adjoining the Syrian border.

Schenley Industries, Inc., in its fiscal year ended Aug. 31 realized a 30 per cent increase in earnings over the preceding fiscal year on a sales gain of 16 per cent, Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 19--President Tito's physicians reported tonight that his aching back was responding to treatment. To complete the Yugoslav leader's recovery, the physicians prescribed "a change of climatic conditions."

A trade official chided ad men yesterday for spreading rumors of a slump.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 19-- An important French military operation is unfolding in the Sahara more than 600 miles southwest of here.
Emilio Pucci, the designer who started the craze for "Italian look" sportswear in this country, has now turned his hand to sweaters.
Advances made by American Negroes in the last fifteen years in employment, education, political participation and economic well-being were hailed last night by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor.
Sixty-two physicists from education and industry will visit 100 colleges this school year to stimulate interest in physics and to aid science teachers. A related project will cover high schools.

Two powerful trucking union locals in this city are engaged in a court fight that may establish the fate of hundreds of millions of dollars in pension funds if the merged labor federation expels the International Brotherhood of Teamsters next month.

The announcement of the trade of Billy Martin of the Kansas City Athletics in a multi-player deal with the Detroit Tigers will be made today The United Press reported last night. Martin, a former Yankee infielder, had been sought by six clubs in the American League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) --Capt. Slade Cutter, the Naval Academy's athletic director, made clear today that the middies wouldn't go to any football bowl game unless they beat Army.
The State Superintendent of Insurance will rule early next year on an application by New York Blue Cross for an average increase of 40 per cent in its premium rate for hospitalization insurance.

New issues of corporate securities amounting to more than $18,000,000 are being offered to investors today. The issues include utility mortgage bonds and common stock and convertible debentures of an industrial concern.
Contrary to the recent trend in the textile industry, record sales and increased earnings were achieved by Burlington Industries, Inc., in its fiscal year ended Sept. 28.

HILLSDALE, Mich., Nov. 19 (AP)--A tiny rural college, every bit as enthused about its team as Oklahoma, today carries the nation's longest current football winning streak. Oklahoma had won forty-seven straight before bowing to Notre Dame last Saturday.
Increases in sales and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 were reported to stockholders of the Electric Storage Battery Company at a special meeting yeserday in Philadelphia.

The Dance Collection of the New York Public Library will benefit frog the Dec. 16 American premiere of "The Bolshoi Ballet" at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. "In a short field, play the outsider" is an old race track maxim.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 19-- Rigid controls over all Palestinian refugees in Lebanon were announced today by the Government as, a move to halt subversive activity. The entry of refugees living in other countries also was barred.
NEWARK, Nov. 19 (AP)--A black cloud with tornado-like winds slashed a ten-second path of destruction through Washington, N. J., today, causing damage of about $100,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov, 19-- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, warned here today that the nation must guard against emulating "the Soviet economy's almost exclusive concern, with military measures" in its effort to meet the Soviet threat.

WESTBURY,L.I, Nov. 19-- The Ten Acre Stables' Clever Braden, a 3-year-old gray colt by Clever Hanover from Milan, Mich., scored a two and onequarter length victry over Hugh Worthy in the Bayville Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Negotiations are well advanced for the sale of R. K. O. Radio Pictures film studios on the West Coast to Desilu Productions, one of the nation's leading producers of television films.
Cotton futures declined 4 to 20 points yesterday in fairly heavy business.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Nov. 19--Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Middendorf of Chestnut Hill and Hamilton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Kennedy Boone Middendorf, to Iver Edward Lofving.
State Controller Arthur Levitt refused yesterday to sell $50,000,000 of state-guaranteed bonds for the financing of the New York State Thruway on terms involving a borrowing cost of 3.449 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -A woman who wrote the first draft of a United States Government report on Soviet education charged today that the final version had contained "misleading and often completely erroneous information."

Harry Van Arsdale Jr., business manager of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, was chosen last night as president of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York.
Mayor Wagner returned yesterday after a ten-day postelection vacation in Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--A former assistant secretary of defense for research and development said today that the United States might be farther ahead with its missile program if exchange of information was less hampered by restrictions.

More than 50,000 employes of the Eastman Kodak Company in the United States will share in the company's largest wage dividend--an estimated $38,200,000-next March. Stockholders, however, will not fare quite so well as last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--A California educator said today that even if states and localities did their utmost, the Federal Government must pay a total of from $5,000,000,000 to $7,000,000,000 of this nation's education bill during the next decade.

E. Townsend Irvin, a stockbroker who long was prominent in the yachting world, died yesterday in Le Roy Hospital. Mr. Arvin, who was 82 years old. lived at 22 East Sixty-fourth Street.

AN almost-forgotten soldier lies in a tomb under the gray granite shaft at the Broadway-Fifth Avenue fork at Twenty-fifth Street. He was lowered into the tomb one hundred years ago, come Monday, when Madison Square was 'way uptown.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted permanent authority to the PanAtlantic Steamship Company of Mobile, Ala., to operate over the old intercoastal routes of the Waterman Steamship Comnany.
LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP)--The International Sugar Council today reimposed sugar export quotas and fixed new ones for participating governments for the remainder of 1957.

CHICAGO Nov. 19 (AP)--Demand for corn futures persisted today despite a forecast of improved weather over most of the rain--sodden grain--producing belt.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19--Emotionally and physically spent from its peak performance in defeating Princeton, the Yale football team started work today for Harvard and the defense of its Big Three title in the bowl here Saturday.

Buddy Adler, executive in charge of production at Twentieth Century-Fox film studios since 1956, has been signed to an exclusive, long-term contract as head of company production. The deal was announced yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president of Fox. approved unanimously by the board of directors.

MURTOSA, Portugal, Nov. 9--This peaceful village on Portugal's northern coast has its bits of America. A gleaming new American auto stands in a cobbled street. The 1957 New Jersey tags look oddly out of place.

The Insurance Company of North America Companies has leased 17,000 square feet, comprising all the space on the sixth floor of the thirty-story office building being constructed at 200 East Forty-second Street by Joseph Durst. Occupany is scheduled for May of next year.
RUSSELL SHERMAN, in his piano recital last night in Town Hall, took on a difficult program that had as many different styles as there were composers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- The Administration is being urged by the Army to make an all-out effort to produce an operational anti-missile missile by 1961 at a three-year cost of between $6,000,000,000 and $7,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19-- Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, hinted today that the Federal Reserve System soon might take new action to ease credit and stimulate the economy.

Michigan State won't get to the Rose Bowl this year, but the Spartans moved to the front yesterday in the battle for the national college football championship by taking first place in the weekly United Press ratings.

HUGO CONSUEGRA is still under 30, and like most painters his age he is restless and searching. In his oneman show at the Roland de Aenlle Gallery, 59 West Fiftythird Street, this Cuban artist offers a record of his search.
DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 20-- Despite protests from some residents, the rebuilding of Tokeneke Road from Old Kings Highway to the Norwalk town line will get under way within a few months.
CHESTERTOWN, Md., Nov. 20--The trend toward shooting high-flying ducks and geese out of the air is getting out of hand around here. Hunters will soon be shooting by radar.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- The United States Chief of Naval Operations, Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, addressed national transportation leaders today on the importance of ocean shipping in war and peace.
JAMSHEDPUR, India, Nov. 12--There's a good case for calling Jamshedpur--an old man's dream that became a town of 250,000--the most important city in India.
An increase of 1,373,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline inventories in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
LONDON, Nov. 20--Differences of opinion in the Cabinet over military economies were believed to have been threshed out today at a meeting of ministers and defense chiefs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Luther A. Huston, a member of The New York Times Washington bureau for twenty-two years, will become Director of Public Information for the Justice Department Dec. 9.
A Belgian stamp dealer yesterday paid $48,000 for two panes of an 1850 issue from his homeland. This is believed the highest bid ever made at a philatelic auction for a single lot.

Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company yesterday cut the fourth-quarter dividend to 20 cents a share from the 35 cents paid in previous quarters. The 20-cent dividend, payable on Dec. 23, brings disbursements this year to $1.25, compared with $1.55 in 1956.
THE Scandinavian designers seem to have their second wind this autumn. New furniture and home accessories from their seemingly ever-fertile design boards have been cropping up all over town.
GENEVA, Nov. 20--Japan renewed her efforts today to obtain a global market for her exports based on principles of liberal trade.
The leader of the thirteen rank-and-file truck drivers who won a court order barring James R. Hoffa from the presidency of the Teamsters Union lost his job with a Queens milk distributor yesterday.

These Menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The victory leaves American Hardware and B.S.F., investment company that controls it, free to carry out announced plans to acquire a greater interest in, and possibly control of, Savage Arms.

Although the scoring was confined to the space of less than half a minute, the thrills abounded down to the end of the National Hockey League game at Madison Squar Garden last night. A crowd of 12,628 saw the New York Rangers battle the Detroit Red Wings to a 1-to-1 tie.

Ken Norton, Manhattan College's basketball coach, this season can cast aside his plaint, "I'm looking for that big man." Height-wise, Norton's current Jasper squad is the best he has had in many seasons.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 20-- The only Democratic member of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors announced here today that he would conduct his own hearing on the county budget two days before the official nearing next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The Defense Department confirmed today the establishment of a central office to direct the development of nuclear power for airplanes and missiles.
Steve Allen's program will be televised live from the Havana Riviera Hotel on Jan. 19 from 8 to 9 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The Post Office Department has established a formal hearing procedure for challenging its rulings that material is not mailable.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP)--Kid Gavilan, a former world welterweight champion, cut loose with a pressing body attack tonight to hammer out a unanimous tenround decision over Walt Byars in Chicago Stadium.
Princeton is quoted as the favorite over Dartmouth in their game for the Ivy football championship in Palmer Stadium Saturday and Coach Bob Blackman of Dartmouth agrees that is proper.
A National Traffic Safety Academy operated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation was proposed here last night by Gov. Frank G. Clement of Tennessee.
The Police Department's campaign against traffic deaths and jaywalking was augmented yesterday by the creation of the Traffic Police Education Unit.
A method by which blackand-white photographs projected on a screen produced the visual sensation of a picture in full color was demonstrated here yesterday.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 20--A synagogue in Levittown, Pa., was the recipient here tonight of a special award for courageously upholding "in the face of hostile public opinion" the principle of racial equality.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Gen. Maxwell Davenport Taylor has suddenly found himself in the center of another fund-seeking battle among the services.
Drivers of ready-mix concrete, sand and gravel trucks voted last night to defer until next April 1 an answer to their employers' "final" contract offer.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 20 --The realities of an educational crisis in this country have been obscured by attitudes toward national strength and by political hostility toward intellectuals, Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, said today.
LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP)--A Soviet physicist declared today that Russia's earth satellites had proved there were billions upon billions of gas particles in space.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 20--Governor Harriman said today that the "Eisenhower-type recession" was at fault for a drop in state revenues. However he declined to say whether the state would continue to forgive part payment of income taxes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Senator Irving M. Ives proposed four major changes in labor laws today.

GLENWOOD LANDING L.I., Nov. 20--The state's political balance of power has shifted to the four suburban counties near New York City, L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, declared today. He said the suburbs might decide the 1958 race for Governor.

A product has to work in the "age of missiles," and too many of them do not, the American Management Association was told yesterday at a manufacturing conference at the Statler Hotel. The speaker was H. Thomas Hallowell Jr., president of the American Standards Association.
KAFR KASIM, Israel, Nov. 20--Israel offered a traditional Arab feast of forgiveness here today in the hope of blotting out one of the darkest moments in her brief history.
TORONTO, Nov. 20(Canadian Press)--Pat Smythe of Great Britain tonight took first place in the international twoand-two team class jumping in the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20--The Soviet Union flaunted its two earth satellites before the United States today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- The United States has quietly released about a fourth of the $40,000,000 in Egyptian assets frozen here since Cairo's seizure of control of the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare denied today a charge that "Education in the U.S.S.R.," a recent Government publication, contained "inaccuracies, deletions and distortions."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Foreign Minister Christian Pineau and Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy paved the way today for an agreement on establishment of United...
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Nov. 20--The National Grange said today that farmers were subsidizing consumers.

Broadway gave its regards to George M. Cohan yesterday. Ground wag broken at Duffy Square, Broadway and Fortysixth Street, for a statue of the late Yankee Doodle Dandy ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20 --A mention of contraceptive pills produced a variance of opinions among three clergymen here today at the New York State Welfare Conference.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 (AP) --The top Congressional investigator of Government secrecy said today the Air Force had got information of Russian sat ellite launching plans months ahead of time but "the Ameri can people were never forewarned."
Americans are still dropping their H's and E's faster than they are buying them, the Treasury reveals.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 20 --The proposal for a federation of Egypt and Syria is gathering momentum.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) --Scheduled airlines are facing economic strangulation because of the Government's "confusing" policies toward civil aviation, an industry spokesman said today.
A woman, blind for eighteen years, detected flashes of light in a recent Los Angeles hospital test in which wires were implanted in her brain.

Cocoa futures fell sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day on the New York Cocoa Exchange. All positions ended the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit lower. The decline continued to be a reaction to the recent sharp rise in the market, in which limit gains were registered on five days.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 20--Thirteen persons arrested in connection with violence over school intergration were found not guilty today in Municipal Court.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20-- The State Department granted a passport today to a Los Angeles lawyer to travel in Communist China and North Korea.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 20--A serious threat to Prime Minister Ismail Ibrahim Chundrigar's five-week-old Government was made today by his senior coalition partners, the Republicans.
The European common market and freetrade area will strengthen common security and spur a new economic revival of the Old World, the Belgian, Foreign Trade Minister, Henry Fayat, said yesterday.

The official announcement that all Regular Army troops will be withdrawn from Little Rock by Thanksgiving should be welcome news to both sides in this searing controversy. Nobody likes the use of Federal troops to enforce the law, though such an extreme demonstration of ...

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and nine United States and Canadian commercial banks lent $32,500,000 yesterday to the Tata Iron and Steel Company, Ltd., largest and oldest steel producer in India.

Publicis, said to be France's largest advertising agency, will open an office here Jan. 1. Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, president of the agency, disclosed this yesterday during an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He had arrived earlier on the Liberte.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 20-- Methods to improve traffic safety were advocated today by Dr. James L. Malfetti, director of Columbia University's newly established Institute for Safety Education.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering today $40,000,000 of Houston Lighting Power Company 4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due Nov. 1, 1987, at a price of 101.608 to yield 4.65 per cent.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20-- Uninterrupted action in 1958 in the nation's urban renewal program was predicted today by the Commissioner of the Federal Urban Renewal Administration.
ALTHOUGH "The Rope Dancers" is small, it is all gold, and it is beautifully acted at the Cort Theatre, where it opened last evening.

Gerard Swope, former president of the General Electric Company and onetime chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, died yesterday at his home, 161 East Seventy-ninth Street. He was 84 years old.
BERNARD BARUCH seems to be standing in double jeopardy for the story of his financial and political career. His personal version, "Baruch: My Own Story," appeared last summer.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in the month ended Nov. 15 to 3,355,437 shares. This was an increase of 747,242 shares from the 2,608,195 shares a month earlier. The total was the largest since March 28, 1932, when the short interest was 3,427,664 shares.

PARIS, Nov. 20--Premier Felix Gaillard was armed today with the power to requisition the services of "indispensable" Government workers to keep essential' services going in the face of a wave of strikes.

PARIS, Nov. 20--The permanent North Atlantic Council discussed today French apprehensions over a reported United States-British plan for the production of nuclear weapons by members of the Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Representative Augustine B. Kelley, Democrat of Pennsylvania, died today in Suburban Hospital in near-by Bethesda, Md. He was 74 years old.
The elegant attire that New Yorkers once wore on distinguished occasions was lifted out of the collections of the Museum of the City of New York and transformed into a living pageant last night.
The city's Commissioner of Air Pollution Control yesterday blamed air pollution, along with cigarette smoking, for recent increases in lung cancer.
The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation and its subsidiaries reported a sharp decline in earnings for the first nine months of this year compared with those a year earlier.
Beleaguered leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are passing the hat to build a defense fund for officials in trouble with the law.
LONDON, Nov. 20--Industrial shares resumed their advance on the stock exchange today. However, prices eased a little in later dealings when the anticipated rally on Wall Street failed to materialize.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20--If an attack were made on North Atlantic Treaty forces "like that on Pearl Harbor," the decision to shoot back would be made by the commanders on the spot, Secretary of State Dulles said here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 (U.P.)--The San Francisco Giants released their 1958 National League schedule today and it showed that twenty-two of the season's first twenty-five games will be played at home.

Arthur M. Loew resigned yesterday as president of Loew's International, the foreign branch of Loew's, Inc. The move foreshadowed the end of the 60year-old film executive's association with the vast film empire founded by his father, the late Marcus Loew, in the nickelodeon era.

The state will seek an order in Westchester Supreme Court next Tuesday directing officers of a New Rochelle housing corporation to accept a Negro family as tenants or face a contempt citation. A contempt citation could result in fines or imprisonment.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz denied yesterday a motion brought by the Board of Education to withhold records sought by a special grand jury investigating lawlessness in Brooklyn schools. He directed that the records be produced at 10 A.M. today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 20--A Chinese Communist official has suggested that a renewal of Peiping's rectification program may be necessary annually or biannually to guarantee national unity and internal security.

GRANDPARENTS exercising their ancient and honorable prerogative of indulging the youngsters in the family--and who can stop them?--received a gentle pat on the back recently from two child study experts.
TORONTO, Nov. 20(U.P.)-- Twenty-one tired members of the Russian hockey team arrived today for the start of a seven-game Canadian tour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--A resolution calling for at least $5,000,000,000 annually in Federal education aid to the states was adopted here today by the National Association of Secretaries of State Teachers Associations.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 20 (AP) --Frederick Sullens, editor of the Jackson Daily News and one of the nation's last personal journalists, died today in University Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 80 years old.
Toward the end of the last century, Emilio Aguinaldo was in the world's headlines. He had successfully led two revolutions against Spain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- The Air Force has placed a policy paper before the Joint Chiefs of Staff taking exception to Army proposals for a major program to develop anti-missile missiles.

The Soviet Union last year gave more than 30,000,000,000 rubles to its research institutions, according to a spokesman for the Soviet regime. This is about $7,500,000,000 at the official exchange rate and $3,000,000,000 at the tourist rate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- The Public Health Service recommended today that the mass X-ray method of finding tuberculosis cases be discontinued.
The Cain Hoy Stable's Nile Lily, a 9-to-1 chance, scored her fourth straight victory yesterday in winning the $23,050 American Beauty Handicap at Jamaica from a field of crack fillies and mares.
Deep interest in classical music and a high degree of professional boxing skill are qualities that are rarely found in one individual.
The Port of New York Authority condemned again yesterday the rental agreement under which the city would lease a proposed new marine terminal to the Holland-America Line.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 20-- David K.E. Bruce, United States Ambassador to Bonn, is scheduled to depart for Washington Friday evening to attend the conversations bewteen Secretary of State Dulles and Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano of West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- Two economists warned today that anti-recession measures taken now might sow the seeds for new inflationary pressures in another year or so.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 20-- The United States is pitting hot jet pilots and the hot jazz trumpet of Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong against the Russians in a continuing propaganda contest in South America.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- For the time being, Neil H. McElroy of Cincinnati, the new Secretary of Defense, is up to his elbows in missiles, but before long his problem will be politics.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 20 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru stressed today the importance of developing closer cooperation between India and the United States to the "largest measure possible" and on a long-term basis.
Tom Greene of Holy Cross is the No. 1 ground gainer among the major-college football players, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
The State of Washington plans to sell $30,500,000 of toll bridge revenue bonds to the Washington State Finance Committee, a division of the government, at an interest cost of about 5 per cent.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it proposed to issue about $720,000,000 in convertible debentures early next year. The issue would be the largest corporate securities offering ever made.
The New Haven Railroad's announcement Tuesday of its intention to seek public subsidies for its commuter service was received coolly yesterday by most of the communities that would be affected.

TODAY, 4 P.M.: "The Princess and the Goblin," a puppet show, will be performed at the Hudson Park Branch of the New York Public Library, 10 Seventh Avenue South. A similar performance will be given tomorrow.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20--New Rochelle has grown in assessed valuations in the last year at a rate three times that of any other city or town in Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The State Department said today that it was seriously concerned about the formation of a coalition Government including Communist leaders, in the Southeast Asian Kingdom of Laos.
Wall Street couldn't make up its mind yesterday. Stocks seesawed much of the day, but ended with a fair gain.

The builders of a large apartment project in downtown Brooklyn have put their rental campaign on wheels. They have begun the use of subway train advertisements in the hope of gaining the attention of riders who may be anxious to forsake country greenery for city convenience.
A rolling mill designed specifically to process "superalloys" and high-speed steels was demonstrated yesterday at Latrobe, Pa., near Pittsburgh, by the Latrobe Steel Company.
FOR the second performance of its season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night presented its box-office success of last season, Gian-Carlo Menotti's madrigal-fable...
North American Aviation, Inc., had record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) --The Tariff Commission was told today that the future of the reciprocal trade agreements program might hinge on the outcome of lead-zinc tariff hearings now under way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20-- The Committee for Economic Development said today that the experience of state development credit corporations in New England and New York had demonstrated that small business needed more funds than it could get through conventional channels.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20--Nat (King) Cole will leave the National Broadcasting Company television network schedule on Dec. 17. The singer said today that because of commitments to make personal appearances here and abroad, he had been forced to turn down an extension of another thirteen weeks.

Moura Lympany's Carnegie Hall recital last night was in the nature of an experiment. It is well known that at the standard ticket scale only three or four living pianists can fill the 2,760 seats of the hall.

SANTIAGO, Spain, Nov. 13 --The Spanish Government has made a striking tourist attraction here by linking one of the world's great Roman Catholic shrines with one of the world's oldest and possibly most sumptuous hotels.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP)--All grain and soybean futures declined today, influenced by improved crop weather, slow demand and a statement by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson that caused increased selling of wheat.

THE forces of classical order and those of surreal ist disquiet in modern French painting are represented respectively by work by Fernand Leger and by Andre Masson at Paul Rosenberg's, 20 East Seventy-ninth Street.
Industry and labor spokesmen clashed yesterday before a joint legislative committee on proposed amendments to the state's labor laws to curb racketeering and corruption in unions.
The Board of Estimate and the Board of Education are considering the feasibility of locating public schools in new commercial and apartment buildings to be constructed with private capital.
Menasha Skulnik and Robert Alda are set to co-star in Henry Denker's comedy "Venus at Large."

Julius Helfand, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday he had warned professional wrestlers and their promoters repeat edly in the past concerning in cidents of the type that led to the riot at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.
The Adams Hotel, a twentytwo-story structure at 2 East Eighty-sixth Street, has been sold by Marvin S. Winter to a syndicate headed by Philip I. Nemiroff and Jack Waltzer.

Many sponsors, including Princess Grace of Monaco, have been announced for the Dec. 5 performance of "Time Remembered" for the benefit of the Guild of the Infant Saviour. Helen Hayes, Susan Strasberg and Richard Burton are starring in the play at the Morosco Theatre.
Nassau County officials opened an all-out campaign yesterday against hoodlums in the garbage disposal racket and other underworld operations.
Governor Harriman announced last night that he had ordered a wide inquiry into the conclave of underworld figures that the state police raided last Thursday in Apalachin, N.Y.

Next in importance to flexibility in central bank monetary policy is the element of "timing." Or perhaps it would be more accurate to say that "timing" represents a logical refinement of the principle of flexibility.
A 9-year-old girl who admitted robbing eight homes in Flushing, Queens, was caught yesterday and taken to Children's Court.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 20-- Turkey has banned the purchase, sale or transfer of all cotton stocks except those owned by Government agencies.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 (UP)--Billy Martin, the fiery infielder who plays for pennants "because that's the only way to play," joined the Detroit Tigers today in a thirteen-player trade with the Kansas City Athletics.
The Fire Department caught up with an arsonist yesterday, only to find its quarry was a 12-year-old girl.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20--The first stage of the trial of Samuel Goldwyn's antitrust suit against Twentieth CenturyFox, National Theatres-Fox West Coast Theatres and other defendants ended yesterday.

The Government of Premier Gaillard has safely passed its first major test by winning a vote of confidence in the National Assembly on a program of "austerity" designed to tide France over her immediate financial difficulties.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture predicted today that the nation's cotton surplus might drop next year to the lowest level since 1953.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 20--Palle Mogensen arrived at the South Pole today to take over the scientific leadership of the United States station for the remainder of the International Geophysical Year.
CAIRO, Nov. 20--Egypt was reported today to have agreed in principle to an offer of Soviet aid that would not bar large-scale dealings in assistance and trade from the West.
Alex Webster was released from St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday, but wasn't permitted to work out with the Giants.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 20 --Lorimer B. Slocum, retired vice president and managing director of the international division of Young Rubicam, Inc., 285 Madison Avenue, New York, advertising agency, died ...

Mrs. Albert C. Santy, chairman of the ninth annual Debu tante Ball of the Junior League of New York, met with her aides at the organization's clubhouse yesterday afternoon to complete arrangements for the fete, which will take place in the Plaza next Wednesday.
DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 21-- Three hundred youngsters listened for an hour today with a minimum of squirming as a string trio played Mozart, Mendelssohn and Haydn.
LONDON, Nov. 21--Britain appeared today to have made scant progress in her effort to improve relations with Yemen.
MIAMI, Nov. 21 (AP)--Bold Ruler arrived at Hileah Park today, giving to the Miami track two claimants to "horse of the year" honors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21-- The National Security Council has accepted Air Force claims for the reliability of the Thor intermediate range ballistic missile.

ANDRE TCHAIKOWSKY has found a pair of lost dates. Engaged to be the soloist at the New York Philharmonic's opening pair of concerts, the 22-year-old Polish-born pianist was the victim of the management-union dispute that caused a delay in the season's start.
Warner Brothers Pictures has appointed Buchanan Co., Inc., to handle its advertising. This follows a trend in the movie industry.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP)-- Attorney Creighton Miller, representing an association of professional players that seeks recognition from the National Football League, today revealed plans for a $4,2OO,000 lawsuit under the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) --Railroad carloadings continued to decline last week, with loadings showing the largest drop in comparison with the previous year for any single week since August, 1954.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 22-- World communism launched a major campaign today to attract the cooperation of all workers, nationalists, socialists and even small capitalists, in the struggle for the ultimate downfall of capitalism.

ALBANY, Nov. 21--The State Board of Regents reaffirmed today its "faith in the American system of education" as it set forth a program for the United States to deal with the Soviet challenge in the sciences.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 21 (AP)--Dearsome, a 3-year-old maiden filly owned by Edna M. Lawless of Allston, Mass., today returned $343.80 for $2 when she won the third race at Naragansett Park. It was the second-highest winning price in racing in the United States this season.

Mrs. Elizabeth Henderson, a spirited cafe society figure whose social exploits kept her in the news even when she was in her energetic seventies, died yesterday at her home, 995 Fifth Avenue. She was 82 years old.
BIG things come in small packages at French Co. whose Christmas Connoisseurs Boutique opens today.

CAN a poor boy from the wrong side of the tracks marry a well-heeled girl from the right side and find happiness? The question was posed last night at the Sullivan Street Playhouse in a piece called "Fall."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 21-- Western Hemisphere lawyers approved today a proposal to set up an inter-American bar foundation. It would seek to bring about greater understanding among lawyers in the hemisphere, where twenty-one legal systems are used.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21--With an inventory of thirty-two new pictures sufficient to accommodate its releasing schedule through February, 1959, Universal-International will slow down the filming of more pictures.
Cotton futures declined 1 to 27 points (5 cents to $1.35 a bale) on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

LAST night at the City Center the New York City Ballet presented its first new work, and the hitherto sluggish young season came to life with a bang. The work in question was George Balanchine's "Square Dance" and it is a gem.
Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N.Y., a middleweight fighter with a lust for work, will box his ninth main event of the year tonight. He meets Bobby Boyd in a ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21-- The commonwealth charged the Philadelphia Orphans Court today with a "patent evasion" of a Supreme Court ruling in the case of two Negro boys seeking admission to Girard College.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (UP) --Sam Hanks, the winner of the 1957 Indianapolis 500-mile big car race, today was honored as auto racing's "man of the year" as he received the first annual United States Auto Club Trophy for his driving achievements.

An angry chairman of the City Planning Commission warned the Board of Estimate yesterday that it must override local opposition if it would have adequate off-street parking facilities in congested areas.
LONDON, Nov. 21--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan is to fly to Paris Monday for talks with Felix Gaillard, the French Premier.

RIGHT from the start of the series, Yale held Harvard in higher regard than any other rival. Admission prices were doubled for The Game, going up from a commonplace two bits to an inflationary four bits. But the series survived that financial juggle. It also survived the first game, a much more formidable barrier.
The Southern Company and its subsidiaries had increased revenues and earnings in October.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) --American professors plan to borrow the "A" to "F" grading system from the classroom and apply it to colleges and universities according to their faculty pay scales.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 21--A stockholders' battle for control of Miami Beach's Fontainebleau Hotel was left up in the air last night as attorneys on both sides presented evidence at a lengthy hearing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.-- (UP)--The Defense Department lifted today the secrecy lid on its guided missile program a little more.
In New York, a spokesman for Penn-Texas said yesterday that the Morse action came as "a complete surprise." Mr. Silberstein could not immediately be reached for comment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) --Thomas E. Murray, former Atomic Energy Commissioner, said today he saw "no objection" to a reopening of the security case of Dr. J. Robert Oppleased if he were to be reinstated."

A billion-dollar hot potato was tossed at the Internal Revenue Service yesterday. A Federal court approved a move to seek a ruling on the tax aspects of the plan to distribute General Motors stock held by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.
New York received a warning yesterday of a new transit strike --this one timed for midnight, Nov. 30.
The downturn in business and the stock market in recent months does not mean the end of the post-war inflation, in the opinion of David Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) --Representative Francis E. Walter said three witnesses questioned by the House Committee on Un-American Activities today about their forbidden Red China trop had declined to answer when asked if they were Communists.
CAIRO, Nov. 21--Egypt's Minister of Industry announced plans today to head a mission to Moscow to work out details of the Soviet Union's offer of economic aid.
The 337th anniversary of the signing of the Mayflower Compact was observed yesterday at the sixty-third annual meeting of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21 (AP)--General Manager Frank Lane of the Cleveland Indians said today he would try to lure Al Rosen, former Cleveland third baseman, out of his one-year retirement.

BELHAVEN, N.C., Nov. 21 --There is something bad ly out of whack with the wild goose situation around here, and a hunter is entitled to hope that nobody will straighten it out soon. Things are going too good.
Virginians by birth or ancestry will gather tonight in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane for a dinner dance sponsored by a society called The Virginians.
Robert K. Christenberry called a seeming truce yesterday in the intraparty battle among New York City Republicans.
Two thousand Jewish pupils paraded through the lower East Side for an hour and a half yesterday in an appeal for more Sabbath observance among the city's Jews.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. Nov. 21--About 1,900 students at Wake Forest College walked good-naturedly out of a chapel session here this morning in further protest of the North Carolina Baptist Convention's ban of on-campus dancing yesterday.

Even under surprise attack from the Soviet Union, the main naval forces in the Atlantic would not reply with atomic weapons unless specifically ordered to do so, Admiral Jerauld Wright said yesterday.
Filmed repeats from Bishop Fulton J. Sheen's program ("Life Is Worth Living") will be televised over Channel 11 beginning Jan. 7.
Five manufacturers of home appliances are mulling over plans to bring the gas refrigerator back to the American market.

Capt. Peter Paul Vucetic, former chief of staff of the old Royal Yugoslav merchant marine and an underground agent in Berlin during part of World War II, died Tuesday in Park West Hospital after a short illness. His age was 67. His home was at 175 Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) --Senate investigators took steps today to force some forty Midwest locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to hand over records on their selection of delegates to the union's October convention. The locals are under the jurisdiction of James R. Hoffa.
WARSAW, Nov. 21--The Communist leaders drew up two declarations. The Yugoslav delegation signed only one of them.
On Monday the rocket that kicked the first Soviet satellite into an earth-girdling orbit is expected to begin making its final appearances over the United States.

The United Nations General Assembly has before it for final vote a resolution reaffirming previous United Nations demands for the peaceful reunification of Korea as an independent and democratic nation.
CAPT. GODFREY WICKSTEED, master of the Mayflower II, luffed into Forty-third Street the other day, breasting the November cold in seventeenth-century jerkin, wool stockings, linsey-woolsey ...
The Board of Estimate yesterday unanimously approved the leasing of a pier at the Hudson River and West Houston Street to the Holland-America Line.

Miss Susan Lonsdale, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Whittaker Lonsdale of 14 Sutton Place South and Mount Kisco, N.Y., will be honored at a dinner to be given by her parents in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Wednesday.
The creation of a large state university centralized on one campus was recommended for the state yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21-- Albert M. Cole, United States Housing Administrator, disclosed today that the Government was considering "a partnership" with private lenders to produce housing "more economically and efficiently for people of modest means."
Alex Webster had his first workout in several days yesterday at Yankee Stadium and all of the New York Giants' coaches said he looked fine. He had been sidelined with an ear infection.
Events today: Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Jack Beeson's "The Sweet Bye and Bye," Juilliard Concert Hall, 120 Claremont Avenue, 8:30.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21-- Cardinal Stritch of Chicago said today that education beyond the classroom was a vital need.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP)-- The management of Fairbanks Morse Co. today said it would seek to have Leopold D. Silberstein held in contempt of court.
W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, believes that an upturn in the textile business is overdue.

TURKEY prices this Thanksgiving will be the lowest in fifteen years. This is the prediction of the New York City Department of Markets. One of the main reasons is the abundance of birds reaching the markets.

Republican State Chairman L. Judson Morhouse was trying to stimulate enthusiasm for his favorite political party when he told a luncheon of the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women that women are "now the most powerful single voting bloc."

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 21-- Negotiations between Iran and Turkey for construction of a $500,000,000 pipeline from Qum in Iran to Turkey's southern port of Iskenderun were suspended today. No date was set for a future meeting.
The Idaho Power Company raised $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of first mortgage bonds due in 1987 at an interest cost of about 4.69 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--A ranking Air Force general disclosed today "active" research programs intended to develop manned ballistic missiles and space platforms.
Yale's efficient use of a backin-motion passing series was conspicuous in the Bulldogs' victory over Princeton last Saturday.

A spokesman for the nation's savings and loan associations said yesterday that the tight mortgage money market might be loosened in 1958, although he added that "loosening does not mean that credit will be easy in the foreseeable future."
J. Henry Lienau of 116 East Sixty-third Street who retired in 1943 as managing director and vice president of the National Sugar Refining Company, died yesterday in his home. His age was 86.

Net income of the United States Plywood Corporation in the three months ended Oct. 31 declined to $2,034,000, or 80 cents a share, from $2,355,700, or 93 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1956. Sales, however, rose to a quarterly high of $54,835,000 from $52,320,000.

Twenty aluminum plaques that will identify distinguished New York buildings and sites were dedicated yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Action on the controversial $205,000,OO0 Lincoln Square slum clearance and redevelopment project was postponed by the Board of Estimate yesterday to a special meeting next Tuesday at 11 A.M. A decision is expected at that meeting.

LONDON, Nov. 21--Prices of most stocks receded today in quiet trading on the stock exchance. Business was restrained by the pending large issue of British Petroleum, uncertainty over the trend on Wall Street and Some disappointing company statements.
Arguments for and against tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway were presented yesterday in a "debate" at a meeting of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--The president of B'nai B'rith advocated today intensified United States aid to underprivileged nations and "accelerated efforts" in achieving political and racial equality among minority groups in this country.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Nov. 21--Israeli and Jordanian military detachments clashed today for the first time in months. Each side accused the other of shooting first.

Morton A. Spring has been named president of Loew's International, succeeding Arthur M. Loew, who submitted his resignation on Wednesday. The company conducts business for Loew's Inc., one of the world's leading motion-picture concerns.

Gross sales of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the nine months ended Oct. 31 totaled $2,772,749,225, an increase of 4.6 per cent over the $2,651,456,408 for the 1956 period, according to the report issued yesterday.

Hartford County, Conn., sold yesterday $3,000,000 of water bonds secured by general taxation to a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and C.J. Devine Co. at an interest cost of 3.0722 per cent.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides and zinc rose; cocoa, copper, lead and rubber declined, and price movements for coffee, sugar and potatoes were mixed.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 22-- Three prominent figures in the racket-riddled garbage collection industry on Long Island entered not guilty pleas today in Nassau County Court to inddictments charging extortion and attempted extortion. All were released on bail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) --President Eisenhower will take part in a political gathering when he goes to Cleveland next Tuesday for the third of his speeches about scientific and defense programs in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 22-- Top leaders of the New Jersey C.I.O. Council said here today that there was "slight likelihood" of a merger with the State Federation of Labor by Dec. 5, as mandated by the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations.

J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the executive committee and former president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, announced yesterday that he would retire as a bank officer at the end of the year. He will continue to serve as a director of the bank.

The deodorant industry is prospering and stabilizing. Trade sources estimate that sales of anti-perspirants this year will amount to $90,000,000, about 600 per cent above 1942 volume. Last year the industry's sales were around 77,000,000.

A stormy session over service on the New York Central's Putnam Division broke up in a deadlock yesterday and somewhat abruptly. The commuters had to make a dash for their trains.

The market for Treasury securities is still looking up, despite the lack of conclusive statistical evidence of a shift of Federal Reserve policy toward active easing of credit.
One of the great buildings erected in Rome by the Emperor Constantine was recently located by archaeologists after long centuries of burial.

The five-story apartment house at 1388 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Fannie Lefkowitz for cash above a first mortgage of $23,893. It was bought by Geisinger Germain through Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers. The sale was the first for the twenty-six-family house since 1924. The building is on a plot 50 by 95 feet. NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 24--One of the oldest cider mills in Fairfield County was also one of the busiest this week-end as it prepared for the pre-Thanksgiving Day rush. Friends and neighbors of the Fairty family, which has operated the mill for thirty years, were manning a production line as efficient as Willow Run's.

In the first week-end of its current season at the City Center, the New York City Ballet restored four ballets to the repertoire and gave repetitions of ten others.
The insurance industry will start court action to compel the state to approve higher automobile liability rates, it announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 24--Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands appealed today to Europe's leading business enterprises to help the advancement of European cultural unity. He asked each enterprise to contribute the equivalent of at least $1,300 a year.

It was a self-induced mystery, generated by a verbal and personal ferocity exhibited chiefly in the General Assembly and the Security Council, and in dealings with the press. The Vishinsky growl and the Gromyko scowl were routine at U.N. sessions.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 --The President's Committee on Scientists and Engineers warned today, that there was little question that the Soviet Union would be superior in science five or ten years from now unless the United States quickly broadened and strengthened its own efforts.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 --President Eisenhower shed his neutrality as Commander in Chief today and openly rooted for the Army team as he watched on television its game with Navy at Philadelphia. However, Navy won, 14-0.

After a hiatus of two years, Soviet high schools are reintroducing courses in international affairs. The decision seems to have been taken so suddenly that there are no textbooks and teachers do not know exactly what to teach. This contrasts vividly with much that we have been hearing lately about the supposed excellence of Soviet education.

THE indoor gardener in search of new plant worlds to conquer might profitably turn to aquatics. Although most often thought of as a functional part of aquariums, underwater plants are handsome enough to grow for their own sake.

THE records of American criminal courts are replete with cases in which innocent persons were sent to prison or executed for crimes they never committed. These injustices have troubled many honest lawenforcement officers as well as the ordinary citizen. One who felt these miscarriages keenly was the late Judge Jerome N. Frank of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 30 --William W. Cowgill has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Meriwether Lewis Cowgill, to George F. Schmid Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Schmid of Bridgehampton, L.I., formerly of Montclair, N.J. The marriage will take place next month.

MAN'S insect enemies, the World Health Organization noted recently, are becoming more menacing than ever. No longer are they so susceptible to the chemical weapons we use in our war on those which bite us, bring us diseases, destroy our possessions and curtail our food supply. We can expect, a rise in the billions of dollars' worth of damage done annually by insects, and in the almost equal amount spent to prevent more harm.
BOMBAY, India, Nov. 29-- William L. Graham, an oilman of 1957 Easy Street in Wichita, Kan., returned to India today with more funds to help young Indian capitalists start new businesses.
